analyzed: bhava paccayā bhikkhave jāti pe  upādāna paccayā bhikkhave bhavaḥ
translated: With existence as condition, monks, comes birth …🔽With clinging as condition, existence …

analyzed: taṇhā paccayā bhikkhave upādānam  vedanā paccayā bhikkhave taṇhā
translated: With craving as condition, clinging …🔽With feeling as condition, craving …

analyzed: phassa paccayā bhikkhave vedanā
translated: With contact as condition, feeling …

analyzed: saḷāyatana paccayā bhikkhave phassaḥ
translated: With the six sense spheres as condition, contact comes to be …

analyzed: nāma rūpa paccayāḥ bhikkhave
translated: With mind and body as condition, the six sense spheres …

analyzed: viññāṇa paccayā bhikkhave nāma rūpam
translated: With consciousness as condition, mind and body …

analyzed: saṅkhāra paccayā bhikkhave viññāṇam
translated: With volitional formations as condition, consciousness …

analyzed: avijjā paccayāḥ bhikkhave saṅkhārāḥ
translated: With ignorance as condition, volitional formations come to be.

original: uppādā vā tathāgatānaṁ anuppādā vā tathāgatānaṁ, ṭhitāva sā dhātu dhammaṭṭhitatā dhammaniyāmatā idappaccayatā.🔽Taṁ tathāgato abhisambujjhati abhisameti.
analyzed: uppādāḥ vā tathāgatānam anuppādāḥ vā tathāgatānam sā dhātu dhamma ṭṭhita tā dhamma niyāma tā idappaccaya tā  tam tathāgataḥ abhisambujjhati abhisameti
translated: Whether or not a Tathāgata appears, that element continues to exist, that property of things persists, that causal relationship holds, that is the way things are, that is the nature of things.

original: Abhisambujjhitvā abhisametvā ācikkhati deseti paññāpeti paṭṭhapeti vivarati vibhajati uttānīkaroti.
analyzed: abhisambujjhitvā abhisametvā ācikkhati deseti paññāpeti paṭṭhapeti vivarati vibhajati uttānīkaroti
translated: The Tathāgata discovers it and penetrates it through direct knowledge, and then he teaches, prescribes, proclaims, establishes, discloses, analyzes, and elucidates it.

analyzed: passatha iti ca āha
translated: He says: ‘See!’

analyzed: avijjā paccayāḥ bhikkhave saṅkhārāḥ
translated: ‘With ignorance as condition, volitional formations come to be.’

original: Iti kho, bhikkhave, yā tatra tathatā avitathatā anaññathatā idappaccayatā—
analyzed: iti kho bhikkhave yā tatra tathatā avitatha tā anaññatha tā idappaccaya tā
translated: Now, bhikkhus, that which is real in this case,

analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhave paṭiccasamuppādaḥ
translated: that is the dependent origination.

analyzed: katame ca bhikkhave paṭiccasamuppannāḥ dhammāḥ
translated: “And what, bhikkhus, are the dependently arisen phenomena?

original: Jarāmaraṇaṁ, bhikkhave, aniccaṁ saṅkhataṁ paṭiccasamuppannaṁ khayadhammaṁ vayadhammaṁ virāgadhammaṁ nirodhadhammaṁ.🔽Jāti, bhikkhave, aniccā saṅkhatā paṭiccasamuppannā khayadhammā vayadhammā virāgadhammā nirodhadhammā.
analyzed: jarāmaraṇa bhikkhave aniccam saṅkhatam paṭicca samuppannam khaya dhammam vaya dhammam virāga dhammam nirodha dhamma  jāti bhikkhave aniccā saṅkhatā paṭicca samuppannā khaya dhammā vaya dhammā virāga dhammā nirodha dhammā
translated: Aging and death are impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated, subject to destruction, subject to vanishing, subject to fading away, subject to cessation.🔽Birth is impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated, subject to destruction, subject to vanishing, subject to fading away, subject to cessation.🔽Existence is impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated, subject to destruction, subject to vanishing, subject to fading away, subject to cessation.🔽Clinging is impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated, subject to destruction, subject to vanishing, subject to fading away, subject to cessation.

original: Bhavo, bhikkhave, anicco saṅkhato paṭiccasamuppanno khayadhammo vayadhammo virāgadhammo nirodhadhammo.🔽Upādānaṁ bhikkhave …pe…🔽taṇhā, bhikkhave …🔽vedanā, bhikkhave …🔽phasso, bhikkhave …
analyzed: bhavaḥ bhikkhave aniccaḥ saṅkhataḥ paṭicca samuppanno khaya dhammo vaya dhammo virāga dhammo nirodha dhammo  upādānam bhikkhave pe  taṇhā bhikkhave  vedanā bhikkhave  phassaḥ bhikkhave
translated: Craving is impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated, subject to destruction, subject to vanishing, subject to fading away, subject to cessation.

analyzed: bhikkhave  bhikkhave  viññāṇa bhikkhave
translated: Feeling is impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated, subject to destruction, subject to vanishing, subject to fading away, subject to cessation.🔽Contact is impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated, subject to destruction, subject to vanishing, subject to fading away, subject to cessation.

analyzed: saṅkhārāḥ bhikkhave
translated: The six sense spheres are impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated, subject to destruction, subject to vanishing, subject to fading away, subject to cessation.🔽Mentality-materiality is impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated, subject to destruction, subject to vanishing, subject to fading away, subject to cessation.🔽Consciousness is impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated, subject to destruction, subject to vanishing, subject to fading away, subject to cessation.🔽Formations are impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated, subject to destruction, subject to vanishing, subject to fading away, subject to cessation.

original: avijjā, bhikkhave, aniccā saṅkhatā paṭiccasamuppannā khayadhammā vayadhammā virāgadhammā nirodhadhammā.
analyzed: avijjā bhikkhave aniccā saṅkhatā paṭicca samuppannā khaya dhammā vaya dhammā virāga dhammā nirodha dhammā
translated: Ignorance is impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated, subject to destruction, subject to vanishing, subject to fading away, subject to cessation.

analyzed: ime vuccanti bhikkhave paṭicca samuppannāḥ dhammāḥ
translated: These are called dependently arisen phenomena.

original: Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa ‘ayañca paṭiccasamuppādo, ime ca paṭiccasamuppannā dhammā’ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhā honti, so vata pubbantaṁ vā paṭidhāvissati:
analyzed: yatas kho bhikkhave ariya sāvakassa ayam ca paṭiccasamuppādaḥ ime ca paṭiccasamuppannāḥ dhammāḥ yathābhūtam sammappaññāya su diṭṭhāḥ honti saḥ vata pubbantam vā paṭidhāvissati
translated: When a noble disciple has seen clearly, in accordance with reality, the dependent origination and these dependently arisen phenomena, it is impossible that he will run back and forth,

original: ‘ahosiṁ nu kho ahaṁ atītamaddhānaṁ, nanu kho ahosiṁ atītamaddhānaṁ, kiṁ nu kho ahosiṁ🔽atītamaddhānaṁ, kathaṁ nu kho ahosiṁ atītamaddhānaṁ, kiṁ hutvā kiṁ ahosiṁ nu kho
analyzed: ahosim nu kho aham atīta maddhāna nanu kho ahosim atīta maddhāna kim nu kho ahosi  atīta maddhāna katham nu kho ahosim atīta maddhāna kim hutvā kim ahosim nu kho
translated: that he will go thus and come thus: ‘Did I exist in the past? Did I not exist in the past? What was I in the past? Having been what, what did I become in the past?

analyzed: aham
translated: Will I exist in the future? Will I not exist in the future? What will I be in the future? Having been what, what will I become in the future?’

analyzed: aparantam vai upadhāvissati
translated: or that he will speculate about the present thus:

original: ‘bhavissāmi nu kho ahaṁ anāgatamaddhānaṁ, nanu kho bhavissāmi anāgatamaddhānaṁ, kiṁ🔽nu kho bhavissāmi anāgatamaddhānaṁ, kathaṁ nu kho bhavissāmi anāgatamaddhānaṁ, kiṁ🔽hutvā kiṁ bhavissāmi nu kho ahaṁ anāgatamaddhānan’ti;🔽etarahi vā paccuppannaṁ addhānaṁ ajjhattaṁ kathaṅkathī bhavissati:
analyzed: bhavissāmi nu kho aham anāgata maddhāna nanu kho bhavissāmi anāgata maddhāna ki 🔽nu kho bhavissāmi anāgata maddhāna katham nu kho bhavissāmi anāgata maddhāna ki 🔽hutvā kim bhavissāmi nu khalu aham anāgatam addhānam ti 🔽etarahi vā paccuppannam addhānam ajjhattam kathaṅkathī bhavissati
translated: ‘Do I exist? Do I not exist? What am I? How am I? Where did I come from? Where am I going?’

original: ‘ahaṁ nu khosmi, no nu khosmi, kiṁ nu khosmi, kathaṁ nu khosmi, ayaṁ nu kho satto kuto āgato, so kuhiṁ gamissatī’ti—
analyzed: aham nu kho asmi no nu kho asmi kim nu kho asmi katham nu kho asmi ayam nu kho satto kutas āgataḥ saḥ kuhim gamissati iti
translated: ‘Am I? Am I not? What am I? How am I? Where has this being come from? Where is it bound?’

analyzed: na itam ṭhānam vijjati

analyzed: tam kim sa hetu

analyzed: imasmin asati idam na hoti imassa nirodhā idam nirujjhati
translated: When this doesn’t exist, that is not; due to the cessation of this, that ceases.

analyzed: yat idam avijjā paccayāḥ saṅkhārāḥ
translated: That is, ignorance is a condition for choices. …

analyzed: saṅkhāra paccayā viññāṇam pe

analyzed: evam etassa kevalassa dukkha kkhandhassa samudayaḥ hoti
translated: This is how there is the origin of this whole mass of suffering.

analyzed: avijjāya tu eva asesa virāga nirodhā saṅkhāra nirodhaḥ

analyzed: evam etassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodhaḥ hoti

original: Evaṁ svākkhāto, bhikkhave, mayā dhammo uttāno vivaṭo pakāsito chinnapilotiko.
analyzed: evam su ākkhātaḥ bhikkhave mayā dhammaḥ uttānaḥ vivaṭaḥ pakāsitaḥ chinna pilotikaḥ
translated: “Bhikkhus, this Dhamma is well expounded by me, open, clear, and free of patchwork, taught by the One with Vision for the sake of complete dispassion, for the fading away of lust, for the deathless, for the realization of Nibbana.

original: Evaṁ svākkhāte kho, bhikkhave, mayā dhamme uttāne vivaṭe pakāsite chinnapilotike alameva saddhāpabbajitena kulaputtena vīriyaṁ ārabhituṁ:🔽‘kāmaṁ taco ca nhāru ca aṭṭhi ca avasissatu, sarīre upassussatu maṁsalohitaṁ. Yaṁ
analyzed: evam su ākkhāte kho bhikkhave mayā dhamme uttāne vivaṭe pakāsite chinna pilotike alam eva saddhāpabbajitena kula puttena vīriyam ārabhitu  kāmam taco ca nhāru ca aṭṭhi ca avasissatu sarīre upassussatu ya
translated: In this Dhamma that is well expounded by me, open, clear, and free of patchwork, taught by the One with Vision for the sake of complete dispassion, for the fading away of lust, for the deathless, for the realization of Nibbana, it is enough to arouse persistence.🔽Let the body dry up right here, let the flesh and blood dry up in the body, but may I not attain any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones without exhausting this perplexity in such a way that it does not remain in any way whatsoever.

original: taṁ purisathāmena purisavīriyena purisaparakkamena pattabbaṁ, na taṁ apāpuṇitvā vīriyassa🔽saṇṭhānaṁ bhavissatī’ti.
analyzed: tam purisa thāmena purisa vīriyena purisa parakkamena na tam apāpuṇitvā vīriyassa 🔽saṇṭhānam bhavissati iti
translated: Let the body dry up right here, let the flesh and blood dry up in the body, but may I not attain any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones without exhausting this perplexity in such a way that it does not remain in any way whatsoever.

original: Dukkhaṁ, bhikkhave, kusīto viharati vokiṇṇo pāpakehi akusalehi dhammehi, mahantañca sadatthaṁ parihāpeti.
analyzed: bhikkhave kusītaḥ viharati vokiṇṇaḥ pāpakehi akusalehi dhammehi mahantam ca sadattham parihāpeti
translated: One who is lazy lives in suffering, overwhelmed by low, unskillful qualities, and fails to fulfill the great good.

original: Āraddhavīriyo ca kho, bhikkhave, sukhaṁ viharati pavivitto pāpakehi akusalehi dhammehi, mahantañca sadatthaṁ paripūreti.
analyzed: āraddha vīriyaḥ ca kho bhikkhave sukham viharati pavivittaḥ pāpakehi akusalehi dhammehi mahantam ca sadattham paripūreti
translated: But one who is energetic lives happily, secluded from low, unskillful qualities, and fulfills the great good.

original: Na, bhikkhave, hīnena aggassa patti hoti.
analyzed: na bhikkhave hīnena aggassa patti hoti
translated: “The foremost is not attained by the lowly,

original: Aggena ca kho, bhikkhave, aggassa patti hoti.
analyzed: aggena ca kho bhikkhave aggassa patti hoti
translated: but the foremost is attained by the foremost.

analyzed: maṇḍapeyyam ida bhikkhave brahmacariya satthā sammukhībhūtaḥ
translated: This spiritual life, monks, is open to the wind, with the Teacher at its head.

original: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, vīriyaṁ ārabhatha appattassa pattiyā, anadhigatassa adhigamāya, asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
analyzed: tasmā ati ha bhikkhave vīriyam ārabhatha appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya a sacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya
translated: So, monks, arouse your persistence to attain the unattained, to achieve the unachieved, to realize the unrealized.

original: ‘Evaṁ no ayaṁ amhākaṁ pabbajjā avañjhā bhavissati saphalā saudrayā.
analyzed: evam naḥ ayam amhākam pabbajjā avañjhā bhavissati saphalā saudrayā
translated: Then this spiritual life of ours will not be empty and fruitless, but will be fulfilled with its fulfillment, and will shine forth in the heaven and the world.

original: Yesañca mayaṁ paribhuñjāma cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṁ tesaṁ te kārā amhesu mahapphalā bhavissanti mahānisaṁsā’ti—

translated: And the service we do for them by using their robe, almsfood, resting place, and medicinal requisites will bring them great fruit and benefit.’

original: “Jānato ahaṁ, bhikkhave, passato āsavānaṁ khayaṁ vadāmi, no ajānato no apassato.
analyzed: jānataḥ aha bhikkhave passataḥ āsavānam khayam vadāmi no a jānataḥ no a passataḥ
translated: “Bhikkhus, I say that defilements should be abandoned through direct knowledge, not through indirect knowledge.

original: Kiñca, bhikkhave, jānato kiṁ passato āsavānaṁ khayo hoti?
analyzed: kiñca bhikkhave jānataḥ kim passataḥ āsavānam khayaḥ hoti
translated: And what is the direct knowledge by which defilements should be abandoned?

original: Iti rūpaṁ iti rūpassa samudayo iti rūpassa atthaṅgamo,
analyzed: iti rūpam iti rūpassa samudayaḥ iti rūpassa atthaṅgamaḥ
translated: ‘This is form, this is the origination of form, this is the cessation of form;

analyzed: iti vedanā pe
translated: this is feeling …🔽this is perception …🔽this is volitional formations …🔽this is consciousness, this is the origination of consciousness, this is the cessation of consciousness.’

analyzed: iti saññā
translated: That is perception. …

analyzed: iti saṅkhārāḥ
translated: That is volitional formations. …

original: iti viññāṇaṁ iti viññāṇassa samudayo iti viññāṇassa atthaṅgamoti.
analyzed: iti viññāṇam iti viññāṇassa samudayaḥ iti viññāṇassa atthaṅgamaḥ ti
translated: That is consciousness. This is the origin of consciousness. This is the ending of consciousness.’

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, jānato evaṁ passato āsavānaṁ khayo hoti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave jānataḥ evam passataḥ āsavānam khayaḥ hoti
translated: “It’s when a monk knows and sees in this way that the destruction of the taints occurs to him.”

original: Yampissa taṁ, bhikkhave, khayasmiṁ khayeñāṇaṁ, tampi saupanisaṁ vadāmi, no anupanisaṁ.
analyzed: yam pi issa ta bhikkhave khayasmim tam pi saupanisam vadāmi no anupanisa
translated: “I say that the knowledge of destruction is dependent, not independent.

analyzed: kā ca bhikkhave khayeñāṇassa upanisā
translated: And what is the support of the knowledge of destruction?

analyzed: vimutti itissa vacanīya
translated: ‘Emancipation,’ should be the reply.

original: Vimuttimpāhaṁ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṁ vadāmi, no anupanisaṁ.
analyzed: vimuttim pāha bhikkhave sa upanisam vadāmi no an upanisa
translated: I say that emancipation is dependent, not independent.

analyzed: kā ca bhikkhave vimuttiyāḥ upanisā
translated: And what is the support of emancipation?

analyzed: virāga ūtiḥ sa vacanīya
translated: ‘Dispassion,’ should be the reply.

original: Virāgampāhaṁ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṁ vadāmi, no anupanisaṁ.
analyzed: virāgam pa aha bhikkhave sa upanisam vadāmi no an upanisa
translated: I say that dispassion is dependent, not independent.

analyzed: kā ca bhikkhave virāgassa upanisā
translated: And what is the support of dispassion?

analyzed: nibbidātissa vacanīya
translated: ‘Disenchantment,’ should be the reply.

original: Nibbidampāhaṁ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṁ vadāmi, no anupanisaṁ.
analyzed: nibbidam pa aha bhikkhave sa upanisam vadāmi no an upanisa
translated: I say that disenchantment is dependent, not independent.

analyzed: kā ca bhikkhave nibbidāya upanisā
translated: And what is the support of disenchantment?

analyzed: vacanīya
translated: ‘Knowledge and vision of things as they really are,’ should be the reply.

original: Yathābhūtañāṇadassanampāhaṁ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṁ vadāmi, no anupanisaṁ.
analyzed: yathā bhūta ñāṇa dassanam pa āha bhikkhave sa upanisam vadāmi no an upanisa
translated: I say that knowledge and vision of things as they really are has a requisite condition, not that it does not have a requisite condition.

analyzed: kā ca bhikkhave yathābhūta ñāṇa dassanassa upanisā
translated: And what is the requisite condition for knowledge and vision of things as they really are?

analyzed: samādhītiḥ sa vacanīya
translated: ‘Concentration,’ should be the reply.

original: Samādhimpāhaṁ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṁ vadāmi, no anupanisaṁ.
analyzed: samādhim pāha bhikkhave saupanisam vadāmi no anupanisa
translated: I say that concentration has a requisite condition, not that it does not have a requisite condition.

analyzed: kā ca bhikkhave samādhissa upanisā
translated: And what is the requisite condition for concentration?

analyzed: sukhantissa vacanīya
translated: ‘Pleasant feeling,’ should be the reply.

original: Sukhampāhaṁ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṁ vadāmi, no anupanisaṁ.
analyzed: sukham pāha bhikkhave saupanisam vadāmi no anupanisa
translated: I say that pleasant feeling has a requisite condition, not that it does not have a requisite condition.

analyzed: kā ca bhikkhave sukhassa upanisā
translated: And what is the requisite condition for pleasant feeling?

analyzed: passaddhi itissa vacanīya
translated: ‘Tranquility,’ should be the reply.

original: Passaddhimpāhaṁ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṁ vadāmi, no anupanisaṁ.
analyzed: passaddhim pa aha bhikkhave sa upanisam vadāmi no an upanisa
translated: I say that tranquility has a requisite condition, not that it does not have a requisite condition.

analyzed: kā ca bhikkhave passaddhiyāḥ upanisā
translated: And what is the requisite condition for tranquility?

analyzed: vacanīya
translated: ‘Rapture,’ should be the reply.

original: Pītimpāhaṁ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṁ vadāmi, no anupanisaṁ.
analyzed: pītim pāha bhikkhave sa upanisam vadāmi no an upanisa
translated: I say that rapture has a requisite condition, not that it does not have a requisite condition.

analyzed: kā ca bhikkhave pītiyāḥ upanisā
translated: And what is the requisite condition for rapture?

analyzed: pāmojjantissa vacanīya
translated: ‘Joy,’ should be the reply.

original: Pāmojjampāhaṁ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṁ vadāmi, no anupanisaṁ.
analyzed: pāmojjam pāha bhikkhave sa upanisam vadāmi no an upanisa
translated: I say that joy has a requisite condition, not that it does not have a requisite condition.

analyzed: kā ca bhikkhave pāmojjassa upanisā
translated: And what is the prerequisite for rapture?

analyzed: saddhātissa vacanīya
translated: ‘Faith,’ should be the reply.

original: Saddhampāhaṁ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṁ vadāmi, no anupanisaṁ.
analyzed: saddham pāha bhikkhave saupanisam vadāmi no anupanisa
translated: I say that faith has a prerequisite, it is not without a prerequisite.

analyzed: kā ca bhikkhave saddhāya upanisā
translated: And what is the prerequisite for faith?

analyzed: dukkhantissa vacanīya
translated: ‘Suffering,’ should be the reply.

original: Dukkhampāhaṁ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṁ vadāmi, no anupanisaṁ.
analyzed: dukkham pa aha bhikkhave saupanisam vadāmi no anupanisa
translated: I say that suffering has a prerequisite, it is not without a prerequisite.

analyzed: kā ca bhikkhave dukkhassa upanisā
translated: And what is the prerequisite for suffering?

analyzed: jāti itissa vacanīya
translated: ‘Birth,’ should be the reply.

original: Jātimpāhaṁ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṁ vadāmi, no anupanisaṁ.
analyzed: jātim pā aha bhikkhave saupanisam vadāmi no anupanisa
translated: I say that birth has a prerequisite, it is not without a prerequisite.

analyzed: kā ca bhikkhave jātiyāḥ upanisā
translated: And what is the prerequisite for birth?

analyzed: bhava ūtiḥ sa vacanīya
translated: ‘Existence,’ should be the reply.

original: Bhavampāhaṁ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṁ vadāmi, no anupanisaṁ.
analyzed: bhavampā aha bhikkhave saupanisam vadāmi no anupanisa
translated: I say that existence has a prerequisite, it is not without a prerequisite.

analyzed: kā ca bhikkhave bhavassa upanisā
translated: And what is the prerequisite for existence?

analyzed: upādāna ntiḥ sa vacanīya
translated: ‘Clinging,’ should be the reply.

original: Upādānampāhaṁ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṁ vadāmi, no anupanisaṁ.
analyzed: upādānam pa aha bhikkhave sa aupanisam vadāmi no an upanisa
translated: I say that clinging has a prerequisite, it is not without a prerequisite.

analyzed: kā ca bhikkhave upādānassa upanisā
translated: And what is the prerequisite for clinging?

analyzed: taṇhātissa vacanīya
translated: ‘Craving,’ should be the reply.

original: Taṇhampāhaṁ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṁ vadāmi, no anupanisaṁ.
analyzed: taṇham pāha bhikkhave saupanisam vadāmi no anupanisa
translated: I say that craving has a condition, not that it is without condition.

analyzed: kā ca bhikkhave taṇhāya upanisā
translated: And what is the condition for craving?

analyzed: vedanātissa vacanīyam pe  phassa utissa vacanīyam
translated: ‘Feeling’ should be the reply. …🔽‘Contact’ should be the reply. …

analyzed: vacanīyam
translated: ‘The six sense spheres’ should be the reply. …

analyzed: vacanīyam
translated: ‘Name-and-form’ should be the reply. …

analyzed: viññāṇa ntissa vacanīyam
translated: ‘Consciousness’ should be the reply. …

analyzed: saṅkhārātissa vacanīya
translated: ‘Formations’ should be the reply.

original: Saṅkhārepāhaṁ, bhikkhave, saupanise vadāmi, no anupanise.
analyzed: saṅkhārepā aha bhikkhave sa upanise vadāmi no an upanise
translated: I say that formations have a condition, not that they are without condition.

analyzed: kā ca bhikkhave saṅkhārānam upanisā
translated: And what is the condition for formations?

analyzed: avijjātissa vacanīya
translated: ‘Ignorance’ should be the reply.

original: Iti kho, bhikkhave, avijjūpanisā saṅkhārā,🔽saṅkhārūpanisaṁ viññāṇaṁ,🔽viññāṇūpanisaṁ nāmarūpaṁ,
analyzed: iti kho bhikkhave avijju upanisāḥ saṅkhārāḥ  saṅkhāra upanisam viññāṇa  viññāṇa upanisam nāma rūpa
translated: So, bhikkhus, ignorance is the condition for formations;🔽formations are the condition for consciousness;🔽consciousness is the condition for name-and-form;

analyzed: nāma rūpa upanisam saṭ āyatana
translated: name-and-form is the condition for the six sense spheres;

analyzed: phassaḥ  vedanā
translated: the six sense spheres are the condition for contact;🔽contact is the condition for feeling;

analyzed: taṇhā  upādāna
translated: feeling is the condition for craving;🔽craving is the condition for clinging;

analyzed: bhavaḥ
translated: clinging is the condition for existence;

analyzed: jāti  jātūpanisam
translated: existence is the condition for birth;

analyzed: dukkha upanisā saddhā
translated: birth is the condition for suffering;🔽suffering is the condition for faith;

analyzed: saddhūpa nisam  pāma ujjū upanisā pi iti
translated: Rapture has happiness as its benefit.🔽Calm has rapture as its benefit.

analyzed: pītu upanisā  sukha
translated: Pleasure has calm as its benefit.

analyzed: samādhi  yathā bhūta ñāṇa dassana
translated: Concentration has pleasure as its benefit.🔽Knowledge and vision of things as they really are has concentration as its benefit.

analyzed: vimutti
translated: Disenchantment has knowledge and vision of things as they really are as its benefit.🔽Detachment has disenchantment as its benefit.🔽Liberation has detachment as its benefit.

analyzed: vimuttu upanisam khayeñāṇa
translated: Knowledge of destruction has liberation as its benefit.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, uparipabbate thullaphusitake deve vassante taṁ udakaṁ yathāninnaṁ
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave upari pabbate thullaphusitake deve vassante tam udakam

Consciousness has volitional formations as its source, its origin, its birth, its arising,🔽their production, their origination. Mentality-materiality has consciousness as its source…

original: vedanūpanisā taṇhā, taṇhūpanisaṁ upādānaṁ, upādānūpaniso bhavo, bhavūpanisā jāti,

Sorrow, lamentation, pain, displeasure, and despair have birth as their source, their origin, their birth, their arising,

analyzed: jātu upanisam dukkha dukkhu upanisā saddhā saddhu upanisam pāmojja pāmojja upanisā pi iti
translated: their production, their origination. Faith has dukkha as its source, its origin, its birth, its arising,🔽their production, their origination. Faith has dukkha as its source, its origin, its birth, its arising,🔽their production, their origination. Joy has faith as its source…

original: pītūpanisā passaddhi, passaddhūpanisaṁ sukhaṁ, sukhūpaniso samādhi, samādhūpanisaṁ
analyzed: pītu upanisā passaddhi passaddhu upanisam sukha sukhu upanisaḥ samādhi samādhu upanisa

translated: Disenchantment has knowledge and vision of things as they really are as its source…🔽Detachment has disenchantment as its source…🔽Knowledge and vision of destruction has deliverance as its source, its origin, its birth, its arising,🔽their production, their origination. Knowledge and vision of destruction has deliverance as its source, its origin, its birth, its arising,

analyzed: sayutta nikāya
translated: their production, their origination.”

analyzed: dasa bala vagga
translated: The third section on ignorance is finished.🔽The Connected Discourses with Outsiders🔽. The Chapter on the One with Ten Powers

analyzed: añña titthiya sutta
translated: Outsiders

analyzed: rājagahe viharati veḷuvane
translated: At Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove.

original: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya rājagahaṁ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
analyzed: atha kho āyasmā sāriputto pubbaṇha samayam nivāsetvā patta cīvaram ādāya rājagaham piṇḍāya pāvisi
translated: Then, when it was morning, he dressed, and taking his bowl and robe, went into Rājagaha for alms.

analyzed: atha kho āyasmataḥ sāriputtassa etat ahosi
translated: Then it occurred to him,

analyzed: atippago kho tāva rājagahe piṇḍāya caritu
translated: “It’s too early to wander for alms in Rājagaha.

original: Yannūnāhaṁ yena aññatitthiyānaṁ paribbājakānaṁ ārāmo tenupasaṅkameyyan”ti.
analyzed: yat nūna aham yena añña titthiyānam paribbājakānam ārāmaḥ tena upasaṅkameyyanti
translated: Why don’t I go to the park of the wanderers of other sects?”

original: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto yena aññatitthiyānaṁ paribbājakānaṁ ārāmo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā tehi aññatitthiyehi paribbājakehi saddhiṁ sammodi.🔽Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho āyasmantaṁ sāriputtaṁ te aññatitthiyā paribbājakā etadavocuṁ:
analyzed: atha kho āyasmā sāriputto yena añña titthiyānam paribbājakānam ārāmaḥ tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā tehi añña titthiyehi paribbājakehi saddhim sammodi  sammodanīyam katham sāraṇīyam vītisāretvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnam kho āyasmantam sāriputtam te añña titthiyāḥ paribbājakāḥ etat avocuḥ
translated: So he went to the park of the wanderers of other sects. On arrival, he exchanged courteous greetings with those wanderers.

original: “Santāvuso sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkataṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti.
analyzed: santi āvuso sāriputte eke samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādā sayaṅkatam dukkham paññapenti
translated: After an exchange of friendly greetings & courtesies, he sat to one side. As he was sitting there, the wanderers said to him, “Friend Sāriputta, there are some contemplatives & brahmans who are proponents of kamma, asserting that pleasure & pain are made by oneself.

original: Santi panāvuso sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā paraṅkataṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti.🔽Santāvuso sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkatañca paraṅkatañca dukkhaṁ paññapenti.
analyzed: santi pana āvuso sāriputte eke samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādā paraṅkatam dukkham paññapenti  santi āvuso sāriputte eke samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādā sayaṅkatam ca paraṅkatam ca dukkham paññapenti
translated: “There are some ascetics and Brahmins who declare that suffering is created by oneself…🔽that suffering is created by another…

original: Santi panāvuso sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā asayaṅkāraṁ aparaṅkāraṁ adhiccasamuppannaṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti.
analyzed: santi pana āvuso sāriputte eke samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādāḥ asayaṅkāram aparaṅkāram adhicca samuppannam dukkham paññapenti
translated: that suffering has arisen fortuitously, being created neither by oneself nor by another.🔽What does the Reverend Gotama say about this?

original: Idha, panāvuso sāriputta, samaṇo gotamo kiṁvādī kimakkhāyī?
analyzed: idha pana āvuso sāriputta samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ ki vādī kimakkhāyī
translated: How does he explain it?

original: Kathaṁ byākaramānā ca mayaṁ vuttavādino ceva samaṇassa gotamassa assāma, na ca samaṇaṁ
analyzed: katham byākaramānā ca mayam vutta vādinaḥ ca iva samaṇassa gotamassa assāma na ca samaṇa
translated: How should we answer if we are to repeat what the Reverend Gotama has said, and not misrepresent him with an untruth?

original: gotamaṁ abhūtena abbhācikkheyyāma, dhammassa cānudhammaṁ byākareyyāma, na ca koci
analyzed: gotamam a bhūtena abbhācikkheyyāma dhammassa ca anudhammam byākareyyāma na ca koci
translated: How are we to understand the doctrine in accordance with the doctrine, and not misrepresent him with an untruth?

analyzed: sahadhammikaḥ vāda anupātaḥ gārayham ṭhānam āgaccheyya ati
translated: How are we to avoid giving the Reverend Gotama an opportunity for saying that we misrepresent him with an untruth?

analyzed: paṭicca samuppannam kho āvuso dukkham vuttam bhagavatā
translated: “Friend, the Blessed One has said that suffering has a specific condition.

analyzed: kim paṭicca
translated: What is that condition?

analyzed: phassam paṭicca
translated: It is contact.

original: Iti vadaṁ vuttavādī ceva bhagavato assa, na ca bhagavantaṁ abhūtena abbhācikkheyya, dhammassa cānudhammaṁ byākareyya, na ca koci sahadhammiko vādānupāto gārayhaṁ ṭhānaṁ āgaccheyya.
analyzed: iti vadam vutta vādī ca iva bhagavataḥ assa na ca bhagavantam abhūtena abbhācikkheyya dhammassa ca anudhammam byākareyya na ca koci sahadhammikaḥ vāda anupātaḥ gārayham ṭhānam āgaccheyya
translated: In saying this, you would be stating what has been said by the Blessed One and would not misrepresent him with what is contrary to fact. You would explain in accordance with the Dhamma, and no reasonable consequence of your assertion would give ground for criticism.

original: Tatrāvuso, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkataṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti tadapi phassapaccayā.🔽Yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā paraṅkataṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti tadapi phassapaccayā.🔽Yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkatañca paraṅkatañca dukkhaṁ paññapenti tadapi phassapaccayā.
analyzed: tatra āvuso ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādā sayaṅkatam dukkham paññapenti tat api phassa paccayā  ye api te samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādā paraṅkatam dukkham paññapenti tat api phassa paccayā  ye api te samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādā sayaṅkatam ca paraṅkatam ca dukkham paññapenti tat api phassa paccayā
translated: “In this regard, friend, those ascetics and brahmins who are proponents of kamma and proclaim the doing of kamma, and who proclaim the doing of kamma and the experience of kamma by oneself, all of them do so depending on and adhering to the six bases of contact.🔽Those ascetics and brahmins who are proponents of kamma and proclaim the doing of kamma, and who proclaim the doing of kamma and the experience of kamma by another, all of them do so depending on and adhering to the six bases of contact.🔽Those ascetics and brahmins who are proponents of kamma and proclaim the doing of kamma, and who proclaim the doing of kamma and the experience of kamma by oneself and by another, all of them do so depending on and adhering to the six bases of contact.

original: Yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā asayaṅkāraṁ aparaṅkāraṁ adhiccasamuppannaṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti tadapi phassapaccayā.
analyzed: ye api te samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādāḥ asayaṅkāram aparaṅkāram adhicca samuppannam dukkham paññapenti tat api phassa paccayā
translated: Those ascetics and brahmins who are proponents of kamma and proclaim the doing of kamma, and who proclaim the doing of kamma and the experience of kamma without specifying a doer, all of them do so depending on and adhering to the six bases of contact.

original: Tatrāvuso, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkataṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.🔽Yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā paraṅkataṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.🔽Yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkatañca paraṅkatañca dukkhaṁ paññapenti, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: tatra āvuso ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādā sayaṅkatam dukkham paññapenti te vata aññatra phassā paṭisavedissanti iti na etam ṭhānam vijjati  ye api te samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādā paraṅkatam dukkham paññapenti te vata aññatra phassā paṭisavedissanti iti na etam ṭhānam vijjati  ye api te samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādā sayaṅkatam ca paraṅkatam ca dukkham paññapenti te vata aññatra phassā paṭisavedissanti iti na etam ṭhānam vijjati
translated: “Friends, those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim suffering is made by oneself and is caused by oneself: it is not possible that they will experience that without contact.🔽“Those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim suffering is made by another and is caused by another: it is not possible that they will experience that without contact.🔽“Those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim suffering is made by oneself and another and is caused by oneself and another: it is not possible that they will experience that without contact.

original: Yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā asayaṅkāraṁ aparaṅkāraṁ adhiccasamuppannaṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī”ti.
analyzed: ye api te samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādāḥ asayaṅkāram aparaṅkāram adhicca samuppannam dukkham paññapenti te vata aññatra phassā paṭisavedissanti iti na etam ṭhānam vijjati iti
translated: “Those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim suffering is causeless and is made without a cause: it is not possible that they will experience that without contact.”

original: Assosi kho āyasmā ānando āyasmato sāriputtassa tehi aññatitthiyehi paribbājakehi saddhiṁ imaṁ kathāsallāpaṁ.
analyzed: assosi kho āyasmā ānandaḥ āyasmataḥ sāriputtassa tehi añña titthiyehi paribbājakehi saddhim imam kathā sallāpa
translated: The venerable Ananda heard the conversation between the venerable Sariputta and the wanderers of other sects.

original: Atha kho āyasmā ānando rājagahe piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.🔽Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando yāvatako āyasmato sāriputtassa tehi aññatitthiyehi paribbājakehi saddhiṁ ahosi kathāsallāpo taṁ sabbaṁ bhagavato ārocesi.
analyzed: atha kho āyasmai ānandaḥ rājagahe piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattam piṇḍapāta paṭikkantaḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdi  ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho āyasmā ānandaḥ yāvatakaḥ āyasmato sāriputtassa tehi añña titthiyehi paribbājakehi saddhim ahosi kathā sallāpo tam sabbam bhagavataḥ ārocesi
translated: and told him what had happened.

original: “Sādhu sādhu, ānanda, yathā taṁ sāriputto sammā byākaramāno byākareyya.
analyzed: sādhu sādhu ānanda yathā tam sāriputto sammā byākaramānaḥ byākareyya
translated: “Good, good, Ānanda! Sāriputta would answer in just the same way.

original: Paṭiccasamuppannaṁ kho, ānanda, dukkhaṁ vuttaṁ mayā.
analyzed: paṭicca samuppannam kho ānanda dukkham vuttam mayā
translated: I have said that suffering has a cause.

analyzed: kim paṭicca
translated: What is the cause?

analyzed: phassam paṭicca
translated: Contact.

original: Iti vadaṁ vuttavādī ceva me assa, na ca maṁ abhūtena abbhācikkheyya, dhammassa cānudhammaṁ byākareyya, na ca koci sahadhammiko vādānupāto gārayhaṁ ṭhānaṁ āgaccheyya.
analyzed: iti vadam vutta vādī ca iva me assa na ca mama abhūtena abbhācikkheyya dhammassa ca anudhammam byākareyya na ca koci sahadhammikaḥ vāda anupātaḥ gārayham ṭhānam āgaccheyya
translated: If you were to say this, you would state what has been said by me and not misrepresent me with what is contrary to fact. You would explain in accordance with the teaching, and no one who speaks in accordance with the teaching would be open to criticism on that basis.

original: Tatrānanda, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkataṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti tadapi phassapaccayā.🔽Yepi te …pe…🔽yepi te …pe…
analyzed: tatra ānanda ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādā sayaṅkatam dukkham paññapenti tat api phassa paccayā  ye pi te pe  ye pi te pe
translated: “Ānanda, those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of kamma and who assert that suffering is created by oneself: this too is conditioned by contact.🔽Those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of kamma and who assert that suffering is created by another: this too is conditioned by contact.

original: yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā asayaṅkāraṁ aparaṅkāraṁ adhiccasamuppannaṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti tadapi phassapaccayā.
analyzed: ye api te samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādāḥ asayaṅkāram aparaṅkāram adhicca samuppannam dukkham paññapenti tat api phassa paccayā
translated: Those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of kamma and who assert that suffering is created by oneself and by another: this too is conditioned by contact.🔽Those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of kamma and who assert that suffering is created neither by oneself nor by another but arises by chance: this too is conditioned by contact.🔽“Ānanda, those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of kamma and who assert that suffering is created by oneself: it is impossible for them to experience anything without contact.

original: Tatrānanda, yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkataṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.🔽Yepi te …pe…🔽yepi te …pe…
analyzed: tatra ānanda ye api te samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādā sayaṅkatam dukkham paññapenti te vata aññatra phassā paṭisavedissanti iti na etam ṭhānam vijjati  ye pi te pe  ye pi te pe
translated: Those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of kamma and who assert that suffering is created by another: it is impossible for them to experience anything without contact.🔽Those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of kamma and who assert that suffering is created by oneself and by another: it is impossible for them to experience anything without contact.

original: yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā asayaṅkāraṁ aparaṅkāraṁ adhiccasamuppannaṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: ye api te samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādāḥ asayaṅkāram aparaṅkāram adhicca samuppannam dukkham paññapenti te vata aññatra phassā paṭisavedissanti iti na etam ṭhānam vijjati
translated: Those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of kamma and who assert that suffering is created neither by oneself nor by another but arises by chance: it is impossible for them to experience anything without contact.

original: Ekamidāhaṁ, ānanda, samayaṁ idheva rājagahe viharāmi veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
analyzed: ekam id āha ānanda samayam idhā iva rājagahe viharāmi veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe
translated: “Ānanda, there is a grove belonging to Queen Mallikā not far from the city.

original: Atha khvāhaṁ, ānanda, pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya rājagahaṁ piṇḍāya pāvisiṁ.
analyzed: atha khvā aha ānanda pubbaṇhasamayam nivāsetvā patta cīvaram ādāya rājagaham piṇḍāya pāvisi
translated: Then, in the morning, I robed up, took my bowl and robe, and entered Rājagaha for alms.

analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: I thought,

analyzed: atippago kho tāva rājagahe piṇḍāya caritu
translated: ‘It’s too early to wander for alms in Rājagaha.

original: Yannūnāhaṁ yena aññatitthiyānaṁ paribbājakānaṁ ārāmo tenupasaṅkameyyan’ti.🔽Atha khvāhaṁ, ānanda, yena aññatitthiyānaṁ paribbājakānaṁ ārāmo tenupasaṅkamiṁ; upasaṅkamitvā tehi aññatitthiyehi paribbājakehi saddhiṁ sammodiṁ.
analyzed: yat nūna aham yena añña titthiyānam paribbājakānam ārāmaḥ tena upasaṅkameyyanti  atha khvā āha ānanda yena añña titthiyānam paribbājakānam ārāmaḥ tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā tehi añña titthiyehi paribbājakehi saddhim sammodi
translated: Why don’t I visit the monastery of the wanderers of other religions?’

original: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁ. Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho maṁ, ānanda, te aññatitthiyā paribbājakā etadavocuṁ:🔽‘Santāvuso gotama, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkataṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti.
analyzed: sammodanīyam katham sāraṇīyam vītisāretvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnam kho me ānanda te añña titthiyāḥ paribbājakāḥ etat avocuḥ  santi āvuso gotama eke samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādā sayaṅkatam dukkham paññapenti
translated: So I went to the monastery of the wanderers of other religions. After I had exchanged friendly greetings with those wanderers, I sat down to one side. The wanderers said to me,🔽‘Reverend Gotama, there are some ascetics and brahmins who declare that suffering is created by oneself.

original: Santi panāvuso gotama, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā paraṅkataṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti.
analyzed: santi pana āvuso gotamaḥ eke samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādā paraṅkatam dukkham paññapenti
translated: There are some ascetics and brahmins who declare that suffering is created by another.

original: Santāvuso gotama, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkatañca paraṅkatañca dukkhaṁ paññapenti.
analyzed: santi āvuso gotama eke samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādā sayaṅkatam ca paraṅkatam ca dukkham paññapenti
translated: There are some ascetics and Brahmins who declare that suffering is created by oneself and by another.

original: Santi panāvuso gotama, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā asayaṅkāraṁ aparaṅkāraṁ adhiccasamuppannaṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti.
analyzed: santi pana āvuso gotama eke samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādāḥ asayaṅkāram aparaṅkāram adhicca samuppannam dukkham paññapenti
translated: There are some ascetics and Brahmins who declare that suffering is created neither by oneself nor by another, but happens fortuitously, being created by chance.

original: Idha no āyasmā gotamo kiṁvādī kimakkhāyī?🔽Kathaṁ byākaramānā ca mayaṁ vuttavādino ceva āyasmato gotamassa assāma, na ca āyasmantaṁ🔽gotamaṁ abhūtena abbhācikkheyyāma, dhammassa cānudhammaṁ byākareyyāma, na ca koci
analyzed: idha naḥ āyasmā gotamo ki vādī kimakkhāyī  katham byākaramānā ca mayam vutta vādinaḥ ca iva āyasmataḥ gotamassa assāma na ca āyasmanta  gotamam a bhūtena abbhācikkheyyāma dhammassa ca anudhammam byākareyyāma na ca koci
translated: What does Master Gotama say about this?🔽How should we answer if we are to repeat what Master Gotama has said, and not misrepresent him with an untruth?

analyzed: sahadhammikaḥ vāda anupātaḥ gārayham ṭhānam āgaccheyya ati
translated: How should we explain in accordance with Master Gotama’s teaching, so that no one could reasonably object and censure us?”

original: Evaṁ vuttāhaṁ, ānanda, te aññatitthiye paribbājake etadavocaṁ:
analyzed: evam vuttā āha ānanda te añña titthiye paribbājake etat avoca
translated: When they had asked this, I replied:

analyzed: paṭicca samuppannam kho āvuso dukkham vuttam mayā
translated: ‘Friends, I have said that suffering is dependently arisen.

analyzed: kim paṭicca
translated: Dependent on what?

analyzed: phassam paṭicca
translated: Dependent on contact.

original: Iti vadaṁ vuttavādī ceva me assa, na ca maṁ abhūtena abbhācikkheyya, dhammassa cānudhammaṁ byākareyya, na ca koci sahadhammiko vādānupāto gārayhaṁ ṭhānaṁ āgaccheyyāti.
analyzed: iti vadam vutta vādī ca iva me assa na ca mama abhūtena abbhācikkheyya dhammassa ca anudhammam byākareyya na ca koci sahadhammikaḥ vāda anupātaḥ gārayham ṭhānam āgaccheyya ati
translated: In saying this, I would be stating what has been said by the Blessed One and would not be misrepresenting him with what is contrary to fact. I would be explaining in accordance with the Dhamma, and no reasonable consequence of my assertion would give ground for criticism.”

original: Tatrāvuso, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkataṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti tadapi phassapaccayā.🔽Yepi te …pe…🔽yepi te …pe…
analyzed: tatra āvuso ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādā sayaṅkatam dukkham paññapenti tat api phassa paccayā  ye pi te pe  ye pi te pe
translated: “Friend, as for those ascetics and brahmins, proponents of kamma, who proclaim the self to be the doer of kamma and to experience the result either here or in the next life, this too is dependent origination.🔽As for those ascetics and brahmins, proponents of kamma, who proclaim the self to be the doer of kamma and to experience the result in some future life, this too is dependent origination.🔽As for those ascetics and brahmins, proponents of kamma, who proclaim the self to be the doer of kamma and to experience the result either here or in the next life or in some future life, this too is dependent origination.

original: yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā asayaṅkāraṁ aparaṅkāraṁ adhiccasamuppannaṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti tadapi phassapaccayā.
analyzed: ye api te samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādāḥ asayaṅkāram aparaṅkāram adhicca samuppannam dukkham paññapenti tat api phassa paccayā
translated: As for those ascetics and brahmins, proponents of kamma, who proclaim the self to be the doer of kamma and to experience the result either through another or itself, this too is dependent origination.

original: Tatrāvuso, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkataṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.🔽Yepi te …pe…
analyzed: tatra āvuso ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādā sayaṅkatam dukkham paññapenti te vata aññatra phassā paṭisavedissanti iti na etam ṭhānam vijjati  ye pi te pe
translated: “Friend, as for those ascetics and brahmins, proponents of kamma, who proclaim the self to be the doer of kamma and to experience the result either here or in the next life, it is impossible that they would experience the result without contact.

analyzed: ye pi te pe
translated: As for those ascetics and brahmins, proponents of kamma, who proclaim the self to be the doer of kamma and to experience the result in some future life…🔽As for those ascetics and brahmins, proponents of kamma, who proclaim the self to be the doer of kamma and to experience the result either here or in the next life or in some future life…

original: yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā asayaṅkāraṁ aparaṅkāraṁ adhiccasamuppannaṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī’”ti.
analyzed: ye api te samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādāḥ asayaṅkāram aparaṅkāram adhicca samuppannam dukkham paññapenti te vata aññatra phassā paṭisavedissanti iti na etam ṭhānam vijjati iti
translated: And those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim that suffering is created by oneself in part and by another in part: it’s impossible for them to experience that apart from contact.”

analyzed: acchariyam bhante abbhutam bhante
translated: “It’s astonishing and amazing, Sir,

original: Yatra hi nāma ekena padena sabbo attho vutto bhavissati.
analyzed: yatra hi nāma ekena padena sabbaḥ attho vuttaḥ bhavissati
translated: that the meaning of a single statement can be so variously expressed.

original: Siyā nu kho, bhante, esevattho vitthārena vuccamāno gambhīro ceva assa gambhīrāvabhāso cā”ti?
analyzed: siyā nu kho bhante esā iva atthaḥ vitthārena vuccamāno gambhīraḥ ca iva assa gambhīra avabhāsaḥ ca ati
translated: But, Sir, would it be possible to explain the meaning of this statement in more detail?”

analyzed: tena ha ānanda tat na eva ittha paṭibhātu uti
translated: “Well then, Ānanda, please explain it yourself.”

analyzed: sace ma bhante evam puccheyyu
translated: “Sir, if I’m asked

original: ‘jarāmaraṇaṁ, āvuso ānanda, kiṁnidānaṁ kiṁsamudayaṁ kiṁjātikaṁ kiṁpabhavan’ti?
analyzed: jarā maraṇe āvuso ānanda ki nidānam ki samudayam ki jātikam
translated: ‘What is the source, origin, birthplace, and inception of old age and death?’

analyzed: evam puṭṭhaḥ uha bhante evam byākareyya
translated: I would answer:

original: ‘jarāmaraṇaṁ kho, āvuso, jātinidānaṁ jātisamudayaṁ jātijātikaṁ jātipabhavan’ti.
analyzed: jarā maraṇam khalu āvuso jāti nidānam jāti samudayam jāti jātikam
translated: ‘Old age and death have birth as their source, origin, birthplace, and inception.’

analyzed: evam puṭṭhaḥ uha bhante evam byākareyya
translated: That’s how I would answer.

analyzed: sace ma bhante evam puccheyyu
translated: If I’m asked this,

original: ‘jāti panāvuso ānanda, kiṁnidānā kiṁsamudayā kiṁjātikā kiṁpabhavā’ti?
analyzed: pana āvuso ānanda ki nidānā ki samudayā ki jātikā
translated: ‘What is the source of birth?’

analyzed: evam puṭṭhaḥ uha bhante evam byākareyya
translated: I would answer like this:

original: ‘jāti kho, āvuso, bhavanidānā bhavasamudayā bhavajātikā bhavappabhavā’ti.🔽Evaṁ puṭṭhohaṁ, bhante, evaṁ byākareyyaṁ.
analyzed: jāti kho āvuso bhava nidānāḥ bhava samudayāḥ bhava jātikāḥ bhava ppabhavāti  evam puṭṭhaḥ uha bhante evam byākareyya
translated: ‘Birth has existence as its source.’🔽If I’m asked this, I would answer like this.

analyzed: sace ma bhante evam puccheyyu
translated: If I’m asked this,

original: ‘bhavo panāvuso ānanda, kiṁnidāno kiṁsamudayo kiṁjātiko kiṁpabhavo’ti?
analyzed: bhavaḥ pana āvuso ānanda ki nidānaḥ ki samudayaḥ ki jātikaḥ ki pabhavaḥ iti
translated: ‘What is the source of existence?’

analyzed: evam puṭṭhaḥ uha bhante evam byākareyya
translated: I would answer like this:

original: ‘bhavo kho, āvuso, upādānanidāno upādānasamudayo upādānajātiko upādānappabhavo’ti.🔽Evaṁ puṭṭhohaṁ, bhante, evaṁ byākareyyaṁ.
analyzed: bhavaḥ kho āvuso upādāna nidānaḥ upādāna samudayaḥ upādāna jātikaḥ upādāna ppabhavaḥ ti  evam puṭṭhaḥ uha bhante evam byākareyya
translated: ‘Existence has grasping as its source.’🔽If I’m asked this, I would answer like this.

original: Sace maṁ, bhante, evaṁ puccheyyuṁ—🔽upādānaṁ panāvuso …pe…🔽taṇhā panāvuso …pe…
analyzed: sace ma bhante evam puccheyyu  upādānam pana āvuso pe  taṇhā pana āvuso pe
translated: If I’m asked this,🔽‘What is the source of grasping?’🔽‘What is the source of craving?’

analyzed: vedanā pana āvuso pe
translated: ‘What is the source of feeling?’

analyzed: sace ma bhante evam puccheyyu
translated: If I’m asked this,

original: ‘phasso panāvuso ānanda, kiṁnidāno kiṁsamudayo kiṁjātiko kiṁpabhavo’ti?
analyzed: phassaḥ pana āvuso ānanda ki nidānaḥ ki samudayaḥ ki jātikaḥ ki pabhavaḥ ti
translated: ‘But, friend Ānanda, what is the source of contact, what is its origin, from what is it born and produced? ’

analyzed: evam puṭṭhaḥ uha bhante evam byākareyya
translated: If I were asked that, venerable sir, I would answer thus:

original: ‘phasso kho, āvuso, saḷāyatananidāno saḷāyatanasamudayo saḷāyatanajātiko saḷāyatanappabhavo’ti.
analyzed: phassaḥ kho āvuso saṅghāyatana nidānaḥ saṅghāyatana samudayo saṅghāyatana jātiko saṅghāyatana ppabhavo ti
translated: ‘Contact has the six sense bases as its source, the six sense bases as its origin, it is born and produced from the six sense bases.’

analyzed: channam tu eva āvuso phassa āyatanānam asesa virāga nirodhā phassa nirodho
translated: ‘With the cessation of the six sense bases, friend, contact ceases.

analyzed: phassa nirodhā vedanā nirodho
translated: With the cessation of contact, feeling ceases.

analyzed: vedanā nirodhā taṇhā nirodhaḥ  taṇhā nirodhāḥ upādāna nirodhaḥ
translated: With the cessation of feeling, craving ceases.🔽With the cessation of craving, clinging ceases.

analyzed: upādāna nirodhāḥ bhava nirodhaḥ
translated: With the cessation of clinging, being ceases.

analyzed: bhava nirodhāḥ jāti nirodhaḥ
translated: With the cessation of being, birth ceases.

analyzed: jāti nirodhā jarā maraṇam soka parideva dukkha domanassa upāyāsāḥ nirujjhanti
translated: With the cessation of birth, old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair cease.

analyzed: evam etassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodhaḥ hoti iti
translated: Thus is the cessation of this whole mass of suffering.’

analyzed: evam puṭṭhaḥ uha bhante evam byākareyyanti
translated: If I were asked that, venerable sir, I would answer in such a way.”

analyzed: catuttha  sayutta nikāya
translated: The fourth

analyzed: dasa bala vagga
translated: The Connected Discourses with Māluṅkyaputta, 4.10

analyzed: bhūmija sutta
translated: With Bhūmija

analyzed: sāvatthiyam viharati
translated: At Sāvatthī.🔽“Bhūmija, when a bhikkhu is an arahant with taints destroyed…🔽he is called a bhikkhu who has attained the consummation of direct knowledge.”

original: Atha kho āyasmā bhūmijo sāyanhasamayaṁ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā sāriputtena saddhiṁ sammodi.
analyzed: atha kho āyasmā bhūmijaḥ sāyanha samayam paṭisallānā vuṭṭhitaḥ yena āyasmā sāriputto tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā sāriputtena saddhim sammodi
translated: Then, in the evening, the Venerable Bhumija came out of retreat, went to the Venerable Sariputta, and exchanged greetings with him.

original: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā bhūmijo āyasmantaṁ sāriputtaṁ etadavoca:🔽“Santāvuso sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkataṁ sukhadukkhaṁ paññapenti.
analyzed: sammodanīyam katham sāraṇīyam vītisāretvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho āyasmā bhūmijaḥ āyasmantam sāriputtam etat avoca  santi āvuso sāriputte eke samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādā sayaṅkatam sukha dukkham paññapenti
translated: When they had concluded their greetings and cordial talk, he sat down to one side and said to the Venerable Sariputta:🔽“Friend Sariputta, there are some recluses and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of kamma and who proclaim a doctrine of becoming according to kamma.

original: Santi panāvuso sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā paraṅkataṁ sukhadukkhaṁ paññapenti.🔽Santāvuso sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkatañca paraṅkatañca sukhadukkhaṁ paññapenti.
analyzed: santi pana āvuso sāriputte eke samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādā paraṅkatam sukha dukkham paññapenti  santi āvuso sāriputte eke samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādā sayaṅkatam ca paraṅkatam ca sukha dukkham paññapenti
translated: There are some recluses and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of kamma and who proclaim a doctrine of becoming according to kamma.🔽There are some recluses and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of kamma and who proclaim a doctrine of becoming according to kamma.

original: Santi panāvuso sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā asayaṅkāraṁ aparaṅkāraṁ adhiccasamuppannaṁ sukhadukkhaṁ paññapenti.
analyzed: santi pana āvuso sāriputte eke samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādāḥ asayaṅkāram aparaṅkāram adhicca samuppannam sukha dukkham paññapenti
translated: There are some recluses and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of kamma and who proclaim a doctrine of becoming according to kamma.

original: Idha no, āvuso sāriputta, bhagavā kiṁvādī kimakkhāyī,🔽kathaṁ byākaramānā ca mayaṁ vuttavādino ceva bhagavato assāma, na ca bhagavantaṁ🔽abhūtena abbhācikkheyyāma, dhammassa cānudhammaṁ byākareyyāma, na ca koci sahadhammiko
analyzed: idha no āvuso sāriputta bhagavā ki vādī kimakkhāyī  katham byākaramānā ca mayam vutta vādinaḥ ca iva bhagavataḥ assāma na ca bhagavanta  abhūtena abbhācikkheyyāma dhammassa ca anudhammam byākareyyāma na ca koci sahadhammikaḥ
translated: “In this matter, friend Sariputta, what is the Blessed One’s view, what does he say,🔽how does he answer if he is asked:🔽‘Venerable sir, is the world finite or infinite?🔽Or is the world finite in one part and infinite in another?🔽Or is the soul the same as the body, or is the soul one thing and the body another?🔽Or does the Tathagata exist after death, or does he not exist after death, or does he both exist and not exist after death, or does he neither exist nor not exist after death?

analyzed: vāda anupātaḥ gārayham ṭhānam āgaccheyya iti
translated: “What does the Blessed One say about this? How should we answer if we’re to state what has been said by him and not misrepresent him with what is unfactual? How are we to answer if we’re to explain in line with the Dhamma and not misrepresent the Dhamma with what is contrary to the Dhamma? How are we to answer if we’re to state what is correct and not get involved in any pointless arguments?”

analyzed: paṭicca samuppannam kho āvuso sukha dukkham vuttam bhagavatā
translated: “Friends, the Blessed One has said that pleasure & pain are dependently co-arisen.

analyzed: kim paṭicca
translated: Dependent on what?

analyzed: phassam paṭicca
translated: Dependent on contact.

original: Iti vadaṁ vuttavādī ceva bhagavato assa, na ca bhagavantaṁ abhūtena abbhācikkheyya, dhammassa cānudhammaṁ byākareyya, na ca koci sahadhammiko vādānupāto gārayhaṁ ṭhānaṁ āgaccheyya.🔽Tatrāvuso, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkataṁ sukhadukkhaṁ paññapenti, tadapi phassapaccayā.🔽Yepi te …pe…
analyzed: iti vadam vutta vādī ca iva bhagavataḥ assa na ca bhagavantam abhūtena abbhācikkheyya dhammassa ca anudhammam byākareyya na ca koci sahadhammikaḥ vāda anupātaḥ gārayham ṭhānam āgaccheyya  tatra āvuso ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādā sayaṅkatam sukha dukkham paññapenti tat api phassa paccayā  ye pi te pe
translated: Thus, in saying this, you would state what has been said by the Blessed One and would not misrepresent him with what is contrary to fact. You would explain in line with the Dhamma, and would not misrepresent the Dhamma with what is contrary to the Dhamma. And any legitimate consequence drawn from your statement would also be legitimate.🔽“Now, friends, in the case of those contemplatives & brahmans who are proponents of kamma, asserting the made & the unmade, pleasure & pain are made by oneself. That too is dependent on contact.

analyzed: ye pi te pe
translated: In the case of those contemplatives & brahmans who are proponents of kamma, asserting the made & the unmade, pleasure & pain are made by another. That too is dependent on contact.🔽In the case of those contemplatives & brahmans who are proponents of kamma, asserting the made & the unmade, pleasure & pain are made by oneself & by another. That too is dependent on contact.🔽In the case of those contemplatives & brahmans who are proponents of kamma, asserting the made & the unmade, pleasure & pain are made by oneself & originate spontaneously. That too is dependent on contact.

original: yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā asayaṅkāraṁ aparaṅkāraṁ adhiccasamuppannaṁ sukhadukkhaṁ paññapenti, tadapi phassapaccayā.🔽Tatrāvuso, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkataṁ sukhadukkhaṁ paññapenti, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: ye api te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ kamma vādāḥ asayaṅkāram aparaṅkāram adhicca samuppannam sukha dukkham paññapenti tat api phassa paccayā  tatra āvuso ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādā sayaṅkatam sukha dukkham paññapenti te vata aññatra phassā paṭisavedissanti iti na etam ṭhānam vijjati
translated: And those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of kamma, and hold the view: ‘Pleasure and pain are created by oneself and by another,’ that too is dependent on contact.🔽“Here, friend, those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of kamma and hold the view: ‘Pleasure and pain are created by oneself,’ can only refer to contact here and now.

analyzed: ye pi te pe  ye pi te pe
translated: Those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of kamma and hold the view: ‘Pleasure and pain are created by another,’ can only refer to contact here and now.🔽Those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of kamma and hold the view: ‘Pleasure and pain are created by oneself and by another,’ can only refer to contact here and now.

original: yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā asayaṅkāraṁ aparaṅkāraṁ adhiccasamuppannaṁ sukhadukkhaṁ paññapenti, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī”ti.
analyzed: ye api te samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādāḥ asayaṅkāram aparaṅkāram adhicca samuppannam sukha dukkham paññapenti te vata aññatra phassā paṭisavedissanti iti na etam ṭhānam vijjati iti
translated: Those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of kamma and hold the view: ‘Pleasure and pain are created neither by oneself nor by another but arise fortuitously, and so pleasure and pain are to be experienced as they happen fortuitously,’ can only refer to contact here and now.”

original: Assosi kho āyasmā ānando āyasmato sāriputtassa āyasmatā bhūmijena saddhiṁ imaṁ kathāsallāpaṁ.
analyzed: assosi kho āyasmā ānandaḥ āyasmataḥ sāriputtassa āyasmatā bhūmijena saddhim imam kathā sallāpa
translated: The Venerable Ananda heard this conversation between the Venerable Sariputta and the Venerable Bhumija.

original: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
analyzed: atha khalu āyasmai ānandaḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdi
translated: Then the Venerable Ananda went to the Blessed One, and after paying homage to him, he sat down at one side

original: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando yāvatako āyasmato sāriputtassa āyasmatā bhūmijena saddhiṁ ahosi kathāsallāpo taṁ sabbaṁ bhagavato ārocesi.
analyzed: ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho āyasmā ānandaḥ yāvatakaḥ āyasmataḥ sāriputtassa āyasmatā bhūmijena saddhim ahosi kathā sallāpo tam sabbam bhagavataḥ ārocesi
translated: and told him what had happened.

original: “Sādhu sādhu, ānanda, yathā taṁ sāriputto sammā byākaramāno byākareyya.
analyzed: sādhu sādhu ānanda yathā tam sāriputto sammā byākaramānaḥ byākareyya
translated: “Good, good, Ānanda! Sāriputta has answered just as I would have.

original: Paṭiccasamuppannaṁ kho, ānanda, sukhadukkhaṁ vuttaṁ mayā.
analyzed: paṭicca samuppannam kho ānanda sukha dukkham vuttam mayā
translated: I have said that pleasure and pain are dependently arisen.

analyzed: kim paṭicca
translated: Dependent on what?

analyzed: phassam paṭicca
translated: Dependent on contact.

original: Iti vadaṁ vuttavādī ceva me assa, na ca maṁ abhūtena abbhācikkheyya, dhammassa cānudhammaṁ byākareyya, na ca koci sahadhammiko vādānupāto gārayhaṁ ṭhānaṁ āgaccheyya.🔽Tatrānanda, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkataṁ sukhadukkhaṁ paññapenti tadapi phassapaccayā.🔽Yepi te …pe…
analyzed: iti vadam vutta vādī ca iva me assa na ca mama abhūtena abbhācikkheyya dhammassa ca anudhammam byākareyya na ca koci sahadhammikaḥ vāda anupātaḥ gārayham ṭhānam āgaccheyya  tatra ānanda ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādā sayaṅkatam sukha dukkham paññapenti tat api phassa paccayā  ye pi te pe
translated: If you were to say this, you would be repeating what I have said, and not misrepresenting me with what is contrary to fact. You would explain in accordance with the Dhamma, and no reasonable consequence of your assertion would give ground for criticism.

analyzed: ye pi te pe
translated: “Ānanda, those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of kamma and insist on the performance of kamma, and who proclaim the performance of kamma to be essential, even they say that pleasure and pain are experienced in dependence on contact.🔽Those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of fate, of nature’s necessity, and of the essential nature of things, and who proclaim the essential nature of beings to be essential, even they say that pleasure and pain are experienced in dependence on contact.🔽Those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of conscious post-mortem existence, and who proclaim the essential nature of beings to be essential, even they say that pleasure and pain are experienced in dependence on contact.

original: yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā asayaṅkāraṁ aparaṅkāraṁ adhiccasamuppannaṁ sukhadukkhaṁ paññapenti tadapi phassapaccayā.
analyzed: ye api te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ kamma vādāḥ asayaṅkāram aparaṅkāram adhicca samuppannam sukha dukkham paññapenti tat api phassa paccayā
translated: And those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of kamma, and who maintain that pleasure and pain are created by oneself and by another, this too is dependent on contact.🔽“Ananda, those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of kamma and who maintain that pleasure and pain are created by oneself: it is impossible for them to experience anything without contact.🔽And those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of kamma and who maintain that pleasure and pain are created by another: it is impossible for them to experience anything without contact.

original: Tatrānanda, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkataṁ sukhadukkhaṁ paññapenti, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.🔽Yepi te …pe…🔽yepi te …pe…
analyzed: tatra ānanda ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādā sayaṅkatam sukha dukkham paññapenti te vata aññatra phassā paṭisavedissanti iti na etam ṭhānam vijjati  ye pi te pe  ye pi te pe
translated: And those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of kamma and who maintain that pleasure and pain are created both by oneself and by another: it is impossible for them to experience anything without contact.

original: yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā asayaṅkāraṁ aparaṅkāraṁ adhiccasamuppannaṁ sukhadukkhaṁ paññapenti, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: ye api te samaṇa brāhmaṇā kamma vādāḥ asayaṅkāram aparaṅkāram adhicca samuppannam sukha dukkham paññapenti te vata aññatra phassā paṭisavedissanti iti na etam ṭhānam vijjati
translated: And those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of kamma and who maintain that pleasure and pain are created neither by oneself nor by another but arise by chance: it is impossible for them to experience anything without contact.

original: Kāye vā hānanda, sati kāyasañcetanāhetu uppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhadukkhaṁ.🔽Vācāya vā hānanda, sati vacīsañcetanāhetu uppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhadukkhaṁ.🔽Mane vā hānanda, sati manosañcetanāhetu uppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhadukkhaṁ avijjāpaccayā ca.
analyzed: kāye vā ha ānanda sati kāya sañcetanā hetu uppajjati ajjhattam sukha dukkha 🔽vācāya vā ha ānanda sati vacī sañcetanā hetu uppajjati ajjhattam sukha dukkha 🔽mane vā ha ānanda sati manaḥ sañcetanā hetu uppajjati ajjhattam sukha dukkham avijjā paccayā ca
translated: “Ananda, when there is the body, because of bodily volition pleasure and pain arise in dependence on a contact.

original: Sāmaṁ vā taṁ, ānanda, kāyasaṅkhāraṁ abhisaṅkharoti, yaṁpaccayāssa taṁ uppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhadukkhaṁ.
analyzed: sāmam vā te ānanda kāya saṅkhāram abhisaṅkharoti ya paccayā assa tat uppajjati ajjhattam sukha dukkha
translated: Either he creates that bodily volitional formation himself, and with that as condition there arises in him suffering or happiness,

original: Pare vā taṁ, ānanda, kāyasaṅkhāraṁ abhisaṅkharonti, yaṁpaccayāssa taṁ uppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhadukkhaṁ.🔽Sampajāno vā taṁ, ānanda, kāyasaṅkhāraṁ abhisaṅkharoti yaṁpaccayāssa taṁ uppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhadukkhaṁ.
analyzed: pare vā te ānanda kāya saṅkhāram abhisaṅkharonti ya paccayā assa tat uppajjati ajjhattam sukha dukkha  sampajānaḥ vā te ānanda kāya saṅkhāram abhisaṅkharoti ya paccayā assa tat uppajjati ajjhattam sukha dukkha
translated: or others create that bodily volitional formation, and with that as condition there arises in him suffering or happiness.🔽Either he creates that bodily volitional formation himself, and with that as condition there arises in him suffering or happiness,🔽or others create that bodily volitional formation, and with that as condition there arises in him suffering or happiness.

original: Asampajāno vā taṁ, ānanda, kāyasaṅkhāraṁ abhisaṅkharoti yaṁpaccayāssa taṁ uppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhadukkhaṁ.🔽Sāmaṁ vā taṁ, ānanda, vacīsaṅkhāraṁ abhisaṅkharoti yaṁpaccayāssa taṁ uppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhadukkhaṁ.
analyzed: a sampajānaḥ vā te ānanda kāya saṅkhāram abhisaṅkharoti ya paccayā assa tat uppajjati ajjhattam sukha dukkha  sāmam vā te ānanda vacī saṅkhāram abhisaṅkharoti ya paccayā assa tat uppajjati ajjhattam sukha dukkha
translated: Either he creates that verbal volitional formation himself, and with that as condition there arises in him suffering or happiness,🔽or others create that verbal volitional formation, and with that as condition there arises in him suffering or happiness.🔽Either he creates that verbal volitional formation himself, and with that as condition there arises in him suffering or happiness,

original: Pare vā taṁ, ānanda, vacīsaṅkhāraṁ abhisaṅkharonti yaṁpaccayāssa taṁ uppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhadukkhaṁ.🔽Sampajāno vā taṁ, ānanda …pe…
analyzed: pare vā te ānanda vacī saṅkhāram abhisaṅkharonti ya paccayā assa tat uppajjati ajjhattam sukha dukkha 🔽sampajānaḥ vā te ānanda pe
translated: or others create that verbal volitional formation, and with that as condition there arises in him suffering or happiness.

original: asampajāno vā taṁ, ānanda, vacīsaṅkhāraṁ abhisaṅkharoti yaṁpaccayāssa taṁ uppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhadukkhaṁ.🔽Sāmaṁ vā taṁ, ānanda, manosaṅkhāraṁ abhisaṅkharoti yaṁpaccayāssa taṁ uppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhadukkhaṁ.
analyzed: a sampajānaḥ vā te ānanda vacī saṅkhāram abhisaṅkharoti ya paccayā assa tat uppajjati ajjhattam sukha dukkha  sāmam vā te ānanda manaḥ saṅkhāram abhisaṅkharoti ya paccayā assa tat uppajjati ajjhattam sukha dukkha
translated: Or he intends the thought-formation verbally, in dependence on which that pleasure and pain arise internally.🔽Or he intends the thought-formation himself, in dependence on which that pleasure and pain arise internally.

original: Pare vā taṁ, ānanda, manosaṅkhāraṁ abhisaṅkharonti yaṁpaccayāssa taṁ uppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhadukkhaṁ.🔽Sampajāno vā taṁ, ānanda …pe…
analyzed: pare vā te ānanda manaḥ saṅkhāram abhisaṅkharonti ya paccayā assa tat uppajjati ajjhattam sukha dukkha  sampajānaḥ vā te ānanda pe
translated: Or others intend the thought-formation for him, in dependence on which that pleasure and pain arise internally.🔽Or he intends the thought-formation himself, in dependence on which that pleasure and pain arise internally.

original: asampajāno vā taṁ, ānanda, manosaṅkhāraṁ abhisaṅkharoti yaṁpaccayāssa taṁ uppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhadukkhaṁ.
analyzed: a sampajānaḥ vā te ānanda manaḥ saṅkhāram abhisaṅkharoti ya paccayā assa tat uppajjati ajjhattam sukha dukkha
translated: Or he intends the thought-formation verbally, in dependence on which that pleasure and pain arise internally.

original: Imesu, ānanda, dhammesu avijjā anupatitā.🔽Avijjāya tveva, ānanda, asesavirāganirodhā so kāyo na hoti yaṁpaccayāssa taṁ uppajjati
analyzed: imesu ānanda dhammesu avijjā anupatitā  avijjāya tu eva ānanda asesa virāga nirodhā so kāyaḥ na hoti ya paccayā assa tat uppajjati
translated: Ignorance has arisen in regard to these things.

original: ajjhattaṁ sukhadukkhaṁ. Sā vācā na hoti yaṁpaccayāssa taṁ uppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhadukkhaṁ.
analyzed: ajjhattam sukha dukkha sā vācā na hoti ya paccayā assa taṃ uppajjati ajjhattam sukha dukkha
translated: With the remainderless fading away and cessation of ignorance that body does not exist, in dependence on which that pleasure and pain arise internally. That speech does not exist, in dependence on which that pleasure and pain arise internally.

original: So mano na hoti yaṁpaccayāssa taṁ uppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhadukkhaṁ.
analyzed: saḥ manaḥ na hoti ya paccayā assa tam uppajjati ajjhattam sukha dukkha
translated: The mind is not, owing to which there would be the arising of pleasure and pain internally.

original: Khettaṁ taṁ na hoti …pe… vatthu taṁ na hoti …pe… āyatanaṁ taṁ na hoti …pe… adhikaraṇaṁ taṁ na hoti yaṁpaccayāssa taṁ uppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhadukkhan”ti.
analyzed: khettam tam na hoti pe vatthu tam na hoti pe āyatanam tam na hoti pe adhikaraṇam tam na hoti ya paccayā assa tam uppajjati ajjhattam sukha dukkham ti
translated: That field is not, that site is not, that foundation is not, that basis is not, that resort is not, that origin is not, that source is not, that forerunner is not, that condition is not, owing to which there would be the arising of pleasure and pain internally.”

analyzed: pañcama  sayutta nikāya
translated: Fifth.

analyzed: dasa bala vagga
translated: The Connected Discourses with Māra, in the first sub-chapter on the ten powers,

analyzed: upavāṇa sutta
translated: With Upavāṇa

analyzed: sāvatthiyam viharati
translated: At Sāvatthī.

original: Atha kho āyasmā upavāṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā upavāṇo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:🔽“Santi pana, bhante, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sayaṅkataṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti.🔽Santi pana, bhante, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā paraṅkataṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti.
analyzed: atha khalu āyasmai upavāṇaḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ khalu āyasmai upavāṇaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca  santi pana bhante eke samaṇa brāhmaṇā sayaṅkatam dukkham paññapenti  santi pana bhante eke samaṇa brāhmaṇā paraṅkatam dukkham paññapenti
translated: Then the venerable Upavāṇa went to the Blessed One, and after paying homage to him, he sat down at one side and said to the Blessed One:🔽“Venerable sir, there are some recluses and brahmins who declare that suffering is created by oneself.🔽There are some recluses and brahmins who declare that suffering is created by another.

original: Santi pana, bhante, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sayaṅkatañca paraṅkatañca dukkhaṁ paññapenti.
analyzed: santi pana bhante eke samaṇa brāhmaṇā sayaṅkatam ca paraṅkatam ca dukkham paññapenti
translated: There are some recluses and brahmins who declare that suffering is created both by oneself and by another.

original: Santi pana, bhante, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā asayaṅkāraṁ aparaṅkāraṁ adhiccasamuppannaṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti.🔽Idha no, bhante, bhagavā kiṁvādī kimakkhāyī kathaṁ byākaramānā ca mayaṁ vuttavādino🔽ceva bhagavato assāma, na ca bhagavantaṁ abhūtena abbhācikkheyyāma, dhammassa cānudhammaṁ
analyzed: santi pana bhante eke samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ asayaṅkāram aparaṅkāram adhicca samuppannam dukkham paññapenti  idha naḥ bhante bhagavā ki vādī kim akkhāyī katham byākaramānā ca mayam vutta vādinaḥ  ca iva bhagavataḥ assāma na ca bhagavantam abhūtena dhammassa ca anudhamma
translated: “But, venerable sir, there are some ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of chance, asserting that ‘Pleasure and pain are produced in beings by chance, not through action, not through volition.’🔽What does the Blessed One say about that?

original: byākareyyāma, na ca koci sahadhammiko vādānupāto gārayhaṁ ṭhānaṁ āgaccheyyā”ti?
analyzed: byākareyyāma na ca koci sahadhammikaḥ vāda anupātaḥ gārayham ṭhānam āgaccheyya ati
translated: How should we answer if we are to state what has been said by the Blessed One and not misrepresent him with what is contrary to fact? How are we to explain in accordance with the Dhamma so that no reasonable consequence of our assertion would give ground for criticism?”

analyzed: paṭicca samuppannam kho upavāṇa dukkham vuttam mayā
translated: “Upavana, I have said that suffering is dependently arisen.

analyzed: kim paṭicca
translated: Dependent on what?

analyzed: phassam paṭicca
translated: Dependent on contact.

original: Iti vadaṁ vuttavādī ceva me assa, na ca maṁ abhūtena abbhācikkheyya, dhammassa cānudhammaṁ byākareyya, na ca koci sahadhammiko vādānupāto gārayhaṁ ṭhānaṁ āgaccheyya.
analyzed: iti vadam vutta vādī ca iva me assa na ca mama abhūtena abbhācikkheyya dhammassa ca anudhammam byākareyya na ca koci sahadhammikaḥ vāda anupātaḥ gārayham ṭhānam āgaccheyya
translated: Thus, Upavana, if one were to speak thus one would be stating what has been said by me and would not misrepresent me with what is contrary to fact; one would explain in accordance with the Dhamma, and no reasonable consequence of one’s assertion would give ground for criticism.

original: Tatra, upavāṇa, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sayaṅkataṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti, tadapi phassapaccayā.
analyzed: tatra upavāṇa ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇā sayaṅkatam dukkham paññapenti tat api phassa paccayā
translated: “Upavana, in regard to this, those ascetics or brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of self-causation, asserting that ‘Pleasure and pain are created by oneself,’ that is dependent on contact.

analyzed: ye pi te pe  ye pi te pe
translated: … those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of conscious post-mortem existence …🔽… those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of unconscious post-mortem existence …

original: yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā asayaṅkāraṁ aparaṅkāraṁ adhiccasamuppannaṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti tadapi phassapaccayā.
analyzed: ye api te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ a sayaṅkāram a paraṅkāram adhicca samuppannam dukkham paññapenti tat api phassa paccayā
translated: … those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of neither perception nor non-perception post-mortem all do so because of contact.

original: Tatra, upavāṇa, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sayaṅkataṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.🔽Yepi te …pe…
analyzed: tatra upavāṇa ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇā sayaṅkatam dukkham paññapenti te vata aññatra phassā paṭisavedissanti iti na etam ṭhānam vijjati  ye pi te pe
translated: “Upavana, those ascetics and brahmins who proclaim a doctrine of self-creation of suffering will not experience anything apart from contact.

analyzed: ye pi te pe
translated: … those who proclaim a doctrine of other-creation of suffering …🔽… those who proclaim a doctrine of both self-creation and other-creation of suffering …

original: yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā asayaṅkāraṁ aparaṅkāraṁ adhiccasamuppannaṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī”ti.
analyzed: ye api te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ a sayaṅkāram a paraṅkāram adhicca samuppannam dukkham paññapenti te vata aññatra phassā paṭisavedissanti iti na etam ṭhānam vijjati iti
translated: … those who proclaim a doctrine of causeless creation of suffering will not experience anything apart from contact.”

analyzed: chaṭṭha  sayutta nikāya
translated: The sixth section on Upavana is finished.🔽The Connected Discourses with Māluṅkyaputta are finished.
