translated: “‘The destruction of birth is Nibbāna’: I see that as it actually is with proper wisdom, yet I am not a perfected one, without pollutants, one cooled.

original: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, kantāramagge udapāno, tatra nevassa rajju na udakavārako.
analyzed: seyyathā api āvuso kantāra magge udapānaḥ tatra na iva assa rajju na udaka vārakaḥ
translated: Suppose there were a well along a desert road, but there was neither a rope nor a bucket.

original: Atha puriso āgaccheyya ghammābhitatto ghammapareto kilanto tasito pipāsito, so taṁ udapānaṁ olokeyya.
analyzed: atha purisaḥ āgaccheyya ghamma abhitattaḥ ghamma pareto kilantaḥ tasitaḥ pipāsitaḥ saḥ tam udapānam olokeyya
translated: Then a man would come along, scorched and exhausted by the hot weather, weary, thirsty, and parched.

original: Tassa ‘udakan’ti hi kho ñāṇaṁ assa, na ca kāyena phusitvā vihareyya.
analyzed: tassa udakanti hi kho ñāṇam assa na ca kāyena phusitvā vihareyya
translated: He would look down into the well and know that there is water there, but he would not be able to touch it or drink it or take it up for drinking.

original: Evameva kho, āvuso, ‘bhavanirodho nibbānan’ti yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhaṁ, na camhi arahaṁ khīṇāsavo”ti.
analyzed: evam eva kho āvuso bhava nirodhaḥ nibbānanti yathābhūtam sammappaññāya su diṭṭha na ca mhi araham khīṇa āsavaḥ ti
translated: In the same way, I see that ‘the destruction of birth is Nibbāna’ as it actually is with proper wisdom, yet I am not a perfected one, without pollutants, one cooled.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, āyasmā ānando āyasmantaṁ paviṭṭhaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte āyasmā ānandaḥ āyasmantam paviṭṭham etat avoca
translated: When this was said, Ven. Ānanda said to Ven. Pavittha,

original: “evaṁvādī tvaṁ, āvuso paviṭṭha, āyasmantaṁ nāradaṁ kiṁ vadesī”ti?
analyzed: eva vādī tvam āvuso paviṭṭhaḥ āyasmantam nāradam kim vadesi iti
translated: “Friend Pavittha, when you said this, what was your meaning?”

original: “Evaṁvādāhaṁ, āvuso ānanda, āyasmantaṁ nāradaṁ na kiñci vadāmi aññatra kalyāṇā aññatra kusalā”ti.
analyzed: evavādā āha āvuso ānandaḥ āyasmantam nāradam na kiñci vadāmi aññatra kalyāṇāḥ aññatra kusalāḥ ati
translated: “Friend Ānanda, when I said this, I meant nothing other than this: ‘I don’t say anything bad about the venerable Nārada. I say only what is good, what is skillful.’”

analyzed: aṭṭhama
translated: The eighth section.

analyzed: sayutta nikāya
translated: Saṁyutta Nikāya 56.10

analyzed: mahāvagga
translated: . The Great Chapter

analyzed: upayanti sutta
translated: Approaching

analyzed: evam me suta
translated: Thus have I heard.🔽On one occasion the Blessed One was dwelling at Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Park.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.🔽Tatra kho …pe…
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme  tatra kha u pe
translated: There the Blessed One addressed the bhikkhus thus:🔽“Bhikkhus, the great ocean, I say, is deep, immeasurable, and difficult to fathom.

original: “mahāsamuddo, bhikkhave, upayanto mahānadiyo upayāpeti, mahānadiyo upayantiyo kunnadiyo🔽upayāpenti, kunnadiyo upayantiyo mahāsobbhe upayāpenti, mahāsobbhā upayantā kusobbhe upayāpenti.
analyzed: mahā samuddaḥ bhikkhave upayantaḥ mahā nadiyaḥ upayāpeti mahā nadiyaḥ upayantiyaḥ kunnadiyaḥ  upayāpenti kunnadiyaḥ upayantiyaḥ mahāsobbhe upayāpenti mahāsobbhā upayantā kusobbhe upayāpenti
translated: So too, I say, the mind is deep, immeasurable, and difficult to fathom.🔽So long, bhikkhus, as I did not directly know as they really are the origin and passing away, the gratification, the danger, and the escape in the case of the mind, I did not claim to have awakened to the unsurpassed perfect enlightenment in this world with its devas, Māra, and Brahmā, in this generation with its ascetics and brahmins, its devas and humans.🔽But when I directly knew all this as it really is, then I claimed to have awakened to the unsurpassed perfect enlightenment in this world with its devas, Māra, and Brahmā, in this generation with its ascetics and brahmins, its devas and humans.🔽And, bhikkhus, as long as I did not directly know as it really is the gratification, the danger, and the escape in the case of the mind, I did not regard myself as freed from bondage to the Lord of Death.

original: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, avijjā upayantī saṅkhāre upayāpeti, saṅkhārā upayantā viññāṇaṁ
analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave avijjā upayantī saṅkhāre upayāpeti saṅkhārāḥ upayantā viññāṇa
translated: But when I directly knew all this as it really is, then I regarded myself as freed from bondage to the Lord of Death.

original: upayāpenti, viññāṇaṁ upayantaṁ nāmarūpaṁ upayāpeti, nāmarūpaṁ upayantaṁ saḷāyatanaṁ🔽upayāpeti, saḷāyatanaṁ upayantaṁ phassaṁ upayāpeti, phasso upayanto vedanaṁ upayāpeti,
analyzed: upayāpenti viññāṇam upayantam nāma rūpam upayāpeti nāma rūpam upayantam saḷāyatana  upayāpeti saḷāyatanam upayantam phassam upayāpeti phassaḥ upayantaḥ vedanam upayāpeti
translated: Consciousness, when arising, makes mentality-materiality arise. Mentality-materiality, when arising, makes the sixfold sense base arise.🔽The sixfold sense base, when arising, makes contact arise. Contact, when arising, makes feeling arise.

original: vedanā upayantī taṇhaṁ upayāpeti, taṇhā upayantī upādānaṁ upayāpeti, upādānaṁ upayantaṁ
analyzed: vedanāḥ upayantī taṇham upayāpa iti taṇhāḥ upayantī upādānam upayāpa iti upādānam upayanta
translated: Feeling, when arising, makes craving arise. Craving, when arising, makes clinging arise. Clinging, when arising, makes

original: bhavaṁ upayāpeti, bhavo upayanto jātiṁ upayāpeti, jāti upayantī jarāmaraṇaṁ upayāpeti.
analyzed: bhavam upayāpa iti bhavaḥ upayantaḥ jātim upayāpa iti jāti upayantī jarā maraṇam upayāpa iti
translated: existence arise. Existence, when arising, makes birth arise. Birth, when arising, makes aging-and-death arise.

original: Mahāsamuddo, bhikkhave, apayanto mahānadiyo apayāpeti, mahānadiyo apayantiyo kunnadiyo
analyzed: mahā samuddaḥ bhikkhave apayantaḥ mahā nadiyaḥ apayāpeti mahā nadiyaḥ apayantiyaḥ kunnadiyaḥ
translated: The great ocean, monks, when receding, makes the great rivers recede. The great rivers, when receding, make the small rivers recede.

original: apayāpenti, kunnadiyo apayantiyo mahāsobbhe apayāpenti, mahāsobbhā apayantā kusobbhe apayāpenti.
analyzed: apayāpenti kunnadiyaḥ apayantiyaḥ mahāsobbhe apayāpenti mahāsobbhā apayantā kusobbhe apayāpenti
translated: The small rivers, when receding, make the large ponds recede. The large ponds, when receding, make the small ponds recede.

original: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, avijjā apayantī saṅkhāre apayāpeti, saṅkhārā apayantā viññāṇaṁ
analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave avijjā apayantī saṅkhāre apayāpeti saṅkhārāḥ apayantā viññāṇa
translated: In the same way, monks, ignorance, when receding, makes the mental formations recede. The mental formations, when receding, make consciousness recede.

original: apayāpenti, viññāṇaṁ apayantaṁ nāmarūpaṁ apayāpeti, nāmarūpaṁ apayantaṁ saḷāyatanaṁ🔽apayāpeti, saḷāyatanaṁ apayantaṁ phassaṁ apayāpeti, phasso apayanto vedanaṁ apayāpeti,
analyzed: apayāpenti viññāṇam apayantam nāma rūpam apayāpeti nāma rūpam apayantam saḷāyatana  apayāpeti saḷāyatanam apayantam phassam apayāpeti phassaḥ apayantaḥ vedanam apayāpeti
translated: consciousness, when ceasing, causes name-and-form to cease. Name-and-form, when ceasing, causes the six sense spheres to cease.🔽The six sense spheres, when ceasing, cause contact to cease. Contact, when ceasing, causes feeling to cease.

original: vedanā apayantī taṇhaṁ apayāpeti, taṇhā apayantī upādānaṁ apayāpeti, upādānaṁ apayantaṁ
analyzed: vedanāḥ apayantī taṇham apayāpa iti taṇhāḥ apayantī upādānam apayāpa iti upādānam apayanta
translated: Feeling, when ceasing, causes craving to cease. Craving, when ceasing, causes clinging to cease. Clinging, when ceasing,

original: bhavaṁ apayāpeti, bhavo apayanto jātiṁ apayāpeti, jāti apayantī jarāmaraṇaṁ apayāpetī”ti.
analyzed: bhavam apayāpa iti bhavaḥ apayantaḥ jātim apayāpa iti jāti apayantī jarā maraṇam apayāpa iti iti
translated: causes existence to cease. Existence, when ceasing, causes birth to cease. Birth, when ceasing, causes old age and death to cease.”

analyzed: navama  sayutta nikāya
translated: The ninth🔽The Connected Discourses with Māra,

analyzed: mahāvagga
translated: The Long Division,

analyzed: susima paribbājaka sutta
translated: With the Wandering Recluse Susima

analyzed: evam me suta
translated: Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe
translated: On one occasion the Blessed One was dwelling at Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove, the Squirrel Sanctuary.

original: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā sakkato hoti garukato mānito pūjito apacito lābhī cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānaṁ.
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena bhagavā sakkataḥ hoti garukataḥ mānitaḥ pūjitaḥ apacitaḥ lābhī cīvara piṇḍapāta senāsana gilāna ppaccaya bhesajja parikkhārāna
translated: Now on that occasion the Blessed One was worshipped, revered, honored, venerated, and given homage—a recipient of robes, alms food, lodgings, and medicinal requisites for the sick.

original: Bhikkhusaṅghopi sakkato hoti garukato mānito pūjito apacito lābhī cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānaṁ.
analyzed: bhikkhu saṅghaḥ api sakkataḥ hoti garukataḥ mānitaḥ pūjitaḥ apacitaḥ lābhī cīvara piṇḍapāta senāsana gilāna paccaya bhesajja parikkhārāna
translated: And the Sangha of monks is honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed, and receives robes, alms-food, dwellings, and medicines.

original: Aññatitthiyā pana paribbājakā asakkatā honti agarukatā amānitā apūjitā anapacitā, na lābhino cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānaṁ.
analyzed: aññatitthiyāḥ pana paribbājakāḥ asakkatāḥ honti agarukatāḥ amānitāḥ apūjitāḥ anapacitāḥ na lābhinaḥ cīvara piṇḍapāta senāsana gilāna ppaccaya bhesajja parikkhārānaṃ
translated: But the monastics of other religions are not honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed, nor do they receive robes, alms-food, dwellings, and medicines.

original: Tena kho pana samayena susimo paribbājako rājagahe paṭivasati mahatiyā paribbājakaparisāya saddhiṁ.
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena susimaḥ paribbājakaḥ rājagahe paṭivasati mahatiyā paribbājaka parisāya saddhi
translated: At that time the wanderer Susīma was staying at Rājagaha with a large assembly of wanderers.

original: Atha kho susimassa paribbājakassa parisā susimaṁ paribbājakaṁ etadavocuṁ:
analyzed: atha kho susimassa paribbājakassa parisā susimam paribbājakam etat avocuḥ
translated: Then the wanderers said to Susīma,

original: “ehi tvaṁ, āvuso susima, samaṇe gotame brahmacariyaṁ cara.🔽Tvaṁ dhammaṁ pariyāpuṇitvā amhe vāceyyāsi.
analyzed: ehi tvai āvuso susima samaṇe gotame brahmacariyam cara  tvam dhammam pariyāpuṇitvā amhe vāceyyā asi
translated: “Come, Susīma, practice the spiritual life under the ascetic Gotama.🔽Learn the Teaching and then tell us.

original: Taṁ mayaṁ dhammaṁ pariyāpuṇitvā gihīnaṁ bhāsissāma.
analyzed: tam mayam dhammam pariyāpuṇitvā gihīnam bhāsissāma
translated: We’ll learn the Teaching and then we’ll tell the householders.

original: Evaṁ mayampi sakkatā bhavissāma garukatā mānitā pūjitā apacitā lābhino cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānan”ti.
analyzed: evam mayam pi sakkatāḥ bhavissāma garukatāḥ mānitāḥ pūjitāḥ apacitāḥ lābhinaḥ cīvara piṇḍapāta senāsana gilāna ppaccaya bhesajja parikkhārānanti
translated: In the same way, we too will be revered, respected, honored, venerated, and we will receive robes, alms-food, dwellings, and medicinal requisites.”

original: “Evamāvuso”ti kho susimo paribbājako sakāya parisāya paṭissuṇitvā yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā ānandena saddhiṁ sammodi.
analyzed: evam āvuso ti kho susimaḥ paribbājakaḥ sakāya parisāya paṭissuṇitvā yena āyasmai ānandaḥ tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā ānandena saddhim sammodi
translated: “Yes, friends,” the wanderer Susima replied to those wanderers. Then he went to Ven. Ānanda and exchanged courteous greetings with him.

original: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho susimo paribbājako āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: sammodanīyam katham sāraṇīyam vītisāretvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho susimaḥ paribbājakaḥ āyasmantam ānandam etat avoca
translated: After an exchange of friendly greetings & courtesies, he sat to one side and said to Ven. Ānanda,

original: “icchāmahaṁ, āvuso ānanda, imasmiṁ dhammavinaye brahmacariyaṁ caritun”ti.🔽Atha kho āyasmā ānando susimaṁ paribbājakaṁ ādāya yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā
analyzed: icchāmahe āvuso ānanda imasmin dhamma vinaye brahmacariyam caritum ti  atha kho āyasmai ānandaḥ susimam paribbājakam ādāya yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā
translated: “Friend Ānanda, I want to lead the holy life in this Dhamma-&-Vinaya.”🔽Then Ven. Ānanda, taking the wanderer Susima with him, went to the Blessed One. On arrival, he

original: bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ khalu āyasmai ānandaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: having bowed down to the Blessed One, sat to one side. As he was sitting there, he said to the Blessed One,🔽“Lord, the wanderer Susima wants to lead the holy life in this Dhamma-&-Vinaya.”

analyzed: bhante susimaḥ paribbājakaḥ evam āha
translated: “Venerable Sir, the wanderer Susīma said this:

original: ‘icchāmahaṁ, āvuso ānanda, imasmiṁ dhammavinaye brahmacariyaṁ caritun’”ti.
analyzed: icchāmahe āvuso ānanda imasmin dhamma vinaye brahmacariyam caritum ti
translated: ‘I wish to practice the spiritual life in this Dhamma and Discipline.’”

analyzed: tena ha ānanda susimam pabbājetha ati
translated: “Well then, Ānanda, give the going forth.”

original: Alattha kho susimo paribbājako bhagavato santike pabbajjaṁ, alattha upasampadaṁ.
analyzed: alattha kho susimaḥ paribbājakaḥ bhagavato santike pabbajja alattha upasampada
translated: And Susīma received the going forth and the full ordination in the presence of the Buddha.

original: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulehi bhikkhūhi bhagavato santike aññā byākatā hoti:
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena sambahulehi bhikkhūhi bhagavato santike aññā byākatā hoti
translated: At that time many monks had declared their enlightenment in the presence of the Buddha,

original: “khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyāti pajānāmā”ti.
analyzed: brahmacariya katam karaṇīya na aparam itthattāya ati pajānāma ati
translated: saying, “We understand: ‘Rebirth is ended; the spiritual life has been fulfilled; the job has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.’”

analyzed: assosi kho āyasmā susimaḥ
translated: The monk Susīma heard about this

original: “sambahulehi kira bhikkhūhi bhagavato santike aññā byākatā:
analyzed: sambahulehi kira bhikkhūhi bhagavato santike aññā byākatā
translated: and thought, “So many monks have declared their enlightenment in the presence of the Buddha, saying,

original: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāmā”ti.
analyzed: brahmacariya katam karaṇīya na aparam itthattāya ati pajānāma ati
translated: ‘We understand: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual life has been fulfilled; the job has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.”’”

original: Atha kho āyasmā susimo yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā tehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṁ sammodi.
analyzed: atha kho āyasmā susimaḥ yena te bhikkhū tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā tehi bhikkhūhi saddhim sammodi
translated: He then went to those monks and exchanged greetings with them.

original: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā susimo te bhikkhū etadavoca:
analyzed: sammodanīyam katham sāraṇīyam vītisāretvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho āyasmā susimaḥ te bhikkhū etat avoca
translated: and after an exchange of friendly greetings, he sat down to one side and said to them:

analyzed: saccam kira āyasmantehi bhagavato santike aññā byākatā
translated: “Is it true that you venerable ones have declared your enlightenment in the presence of the Buddha,

original: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāmā”ti?
analyzed: brahmacariya katam karaṇīya na aparam itthattāya ati pajānāma ati
translated: announcing: ‘We understand: Destroyed is birth, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more coming back to any state of being’?”

analyzed: evam āvuso iti
translated: “Yes, friend.”

original: “Api pana tumhe āyasmanto evaṁ jānantā evaṁ passantā anekavihitaṁ iddhividhaṁ paccanubhotha—ekopi🔽hutvā bahudhā hotha, bahudhāpi hutvā eko hotha; āvibhāvaṁ, tirobhāvaṁ, tirokuṭṭaṁ
analyzed: api pana tumhe āyasmantaḥ evam jānantāḥ evam passantāḥ aneka vihitam iddhi vidham paccanubhotha ekaḥ pi  hutvā bahudhā hotha bahudhā api hutvā ekaḥ hotha āvi bhāva tirobhāva tirokuṭṭa
translated: “But, venerable friends, do you, knowing and seeing thus, enjoy the various kinds of psychic potency: having been one, becoming many…🔽making the earth quake?🔽Do you exercise mastery with the body as far as the brahma world?🔽Do you recollect your manifold past abodes with their modes and details?

original: tiropākāraṁ tiropabbataṁ asajjamānā gacchatha, seyyathāpi ākāse; pathaviyāpi ummujjanimujjaṁ🔽karotha, seyyathāpi udake; udakepi abhijjamāne gacchatha, seyyathāpi pathaviyaṁ;
analyzed: tiro upākāram tiro pabbatam a sajjamānāḥ gacchatha seyyathā api ākāse pathaviyā api ummujja nimujja 🔽karotha sā iyyathā api udake udake pi abhijjamāne gacchatha sā iyyathā api pathaviya
translated: Do you with the divine eye, which is purified and surpasses the human, see beings passing away and reappearing, inferior and superior, fair and ugly, fortunate and unfortunate, and understand how beings pass on according to their actions?

original: ākāsepi pallaṅkena kamatha, seyyathāpi pakkhī sakuṇo; imepi candimasūriye evaṁmahiddhike
analyzed: ākāse pi pallaṅkena kamatha seyyathā api pakkhī sakuṇaḥ ime pi candima sūriye evam ahiddhike
translated: “Can you fly through the air cross-legged, like a bird with wings?🔽Can you touch and stroke with your hand this moon and sun, so mighty and powerful?🔽Can you exercise the various kinds of psychic potency: having been one, become many; having been many, become one;

original: evaṁmahānubhāve pāṇinā parimasatha parimajjatha, yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṁ vattethā”ti?
analyzed: evam ahā anubhāve pāṇinā parimasatha parimajjatha yāva kāyena vasam vattetha ati
translated: appear and vanish; go unimpeded through walls, through enclosures, through mountains, as though through space; dive in and out of the earth as though through water; walk on water without sinking as though it were dry land; fly cross-legged through the sky like a bird with wings; with your hand touch and stroke even as far as the world of Brahmā?

analyzed: na u ha itas āvuso
translated: “No, friend.”

original: “Api pana tumhe āyasmanto evaṁ jānantā evaṁ passantā dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya ubho sadde suṇātha dibbe ca mānuse ca ye dūre santike cā”ti?
analyzed: api pana tumhe āyasmantaḥ evam jānantāḥ evam passantāḥ dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkanta mānusikāya ubho sadde suṇātha dibbe ca mānuse ca ye dūre santike ca ati
translated: “Can you, with the divine ear element, which is purified and surpasses the human, hear both kinds of sounds, the divine and human, those that are far as well as near?”

original: “No hetaṁ, āvuso”.🔽“Api pana tumhe āyasmanto evaṁ jānantā evaṁ passantā parasattānaṁ parapuggalānaṁ cetasā ceto paricca pajānātha—🔽sarāgaṁ vā cittaṁ sarāgaṁ cittanti pajānātha;
analyzed: na u ha itas āvuso  api pana tumhe āyasmantaḥ evam jānantā evam passantā para sattānam para puggalānam cetasā cetaḥ paricca pajānātha  sa rāgam vā cittam sa rāgam cittam iti pajānātha
translated: “No, friend.”

original: vītarāgaṁ vā cittaṁ vītarāgaṁ cittanti pajānātha;🔽sadosaṁ vā cittaṁ sadosaṁ cittanti pajānātha;
analyzed: vīta rāgam vā cittam vīta rāgam cittam iti pajānātha  sa dosam vā cittam sa dosam cittam iti pajānātha
translated: “Can you, with the divine eye, which is purified and surpasses the human, see beings passing away and arising: base and noble, well favored and ill favored, to happy and unhappy destinations as kamma directs them, and know: ‘These beings, on account of misconduct of body, speech, and mind, on account of defiling actions and words and views, are of bad character, of bad behavior, and when their body breaks up, after death, have reappeared in a plane of deprivation, a bad destination, a lower realm, hell?

original: vītadosaṁ vā cittaṁ vītadosaṁ cittanti pajānātha;
analyzed: vīta dosam vā cittam vīta dosam cittam iti pajānātha
translated: “Can you, with the divine eye, which is purified and surpasses the human, see beings passing away and arising: base and noble, well favored and ill favored, to happy and unhappy destinations as kamma directs them, and know: ‘These beings, on account of good conduct of body, speech, and mind, on account of wholesome actions and words and views, are of good character, of good behavior, and when their body breaks up, after death, have reappeared in a good destination, a heavenly world?’

original: samohaṁ vā cittaṁ samohaṁ cittanti pajānātha;
analyzed: sa moham vā cittam sa moham cittam iti pajānātha
translated: a mind with delusion as a mind with delusion,

original: vītamohaṁ vā cittaṁ vītamohaṁ cittanti pajānātha;🔽saṅkhittaṁ vā cittaṁ saṅkhittaṁ cittanti pajānātha;
analyzed: vīta moham vā cittam vīta moham cittam iti pajānātha  saṅkhittam vā cittam saṅkhittam cittam iti pajānātha
translated: a mind without delusion as a mind without delusion,🔽a contracted mind as contracted,

original: vikkhittaṁ vā cittaṁ vikkhittaṁ cittanti pajānātha;🔽mahaggataṁ vā cittaṁ mahaggataṁ cittanti pajānātha;
analyzed: vikkhittam vā cittam vikkhittam cittan ti pajānātha  mahaggatam vā cittam mahaggatam cittam iti pajānātha
translated: a distracted mind as distracted,🔽a developed mind as developed,

original: amahaggataṁ vā cittaṁ amahaggataṁ cittanti pajānātha;🔽sauttaraṁ vā cittaṁ sauttaraṁ cittanti pajānātha;
analyzed: a mahaggatam vā cittam a mahaggatam cittam iti pajānātha  sauttaram vā cittam sauttaram cittam iti pajānātha
translated: an undeveloped mind as undeveloped,🔽a surpassed mind as surpassed,

original: anuttaraṁ vā cittaṁ anuttaraṁ cittanti pajānātha;🔽samāhitaṁ vā cittaṁ samāhitaṁ cittanti pajānātha;
analyzed: anuttaram vā cittam anuttaram cittam iti pajānātha  samāhitam vā cittam samāhitam cittam iti pajānātha
translated: an unsurpassed mind as unsurpassed,🔽a concentrated mind as concentrated,

original: asamāhitaṁ vā cittaṁ asamāhitaṁ cittanti pajānātha;🔽vimuttaṁ vā cittaṁ vimuttaṁ cittanti pajānātha;
analyzed: a samāhitam vā cittam a samāhitam cittam iti pajānātha  vimuttam vā cittam vimuttam cittam iti pajānātha
translated: an unconcentrated mind as unconcentrated,🔽a liberated mind as liberated,

original: avimuttaṁ vā cittaṁ avimuttaṁ cittanti pajānāthā”ti?
analyzed: a vimuttam vā cittam a vimuttam cittam iti pajānātha ati
translated: and an unliberated mind as unliberated?”

analyzed: na u ha itas āvuso
translated: “No, friend.”

original: “Api pana tumhe āyasmanto evaṁ jānantā evaṁ passantā anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussaratha,
analyzed: api pana tumhe āyasmantaḥ evam jānantāḥ evam passantāḥ aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussaratha
translated: “But, venerable sirs, knowing and seeing thus, do you recollect your manifold past abodes with their modes and details?”🔽“That is, one birth, two, three, four, five,

original: seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo🔽dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattārīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo🔽jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi, anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe
analyzed: sā iyyathidam ekam pi jātim dve pi jātiyaḥ tisso api jātiyaḥ catasso pi jātiyaḥ pañca api jātiyaḥ  dasa api jātiyaḥ vīsampi jātiyaḥ tisampi jātiyaḥ cattārīsampi jātiyaḥ paññāsampi jātiyaḥ  jāti satam pi jāti sahassam pi jāti sata sahassam pi aneke pi savaṭṭa kappe aneke pi vivaṭṭa kappe
translated: ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty,

original: anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhapaṭisaṁvedī
analyzed: aneke pi sa vaṭṭa vivaṭṭa kappe amutra asim eva nāmaḥ evaṃgottaḥ eva vaṇṇo evam āhāro eva sukha dukkha paṭisavedī
translated: a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand births; many eons of world-dissolution, many eons of world-evolution, many eons of world-dissolution and evolution: ‘There I was so named, of such a race, with such an appearance, such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such the end of my life;

original: evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo🔽evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhapaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti.
analyzed: evam āyu pariyantaḥ saḥ tatas cutaḥ amutra udapādi eva nāmaḥ evaṅgottaḥ eva vaṇṇaḥ  evam āhāraḥ eva sukha dukkha paṭisavedī evam āyu pariyanto saḥ tatas cutaḥ idhu upapanno ti
translated: and passing away from there, I reappeared elsewhere; and there too I was so named, of such a race, with such an appearance, such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such the end of my life;

original: Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarathā”ti?
analyzed: iti sa ākāram sa uddesam aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussaratha ati
translated: and passing away from there, I reappeared here.’ Thus with their modes and details do you recollect your manifold past abodes?”

analyzed: na u ha itas āvuso
translated: “No, friend.”

original: “Api pana tumhe āyasmanto evaṁ jānantā evaṁ passantā dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena🔽atikkantamānusakena satte passatha cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe,🔽sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānātha: ‘ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena
analyzed: api pana tumhe āyasmantaḥ evam jānantāḥ evam passantāḥ dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena  atikkanta mānusakena satte passatha cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe  sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānātha ime vata bhonto sattā kāya duccaritena
translated: “Then, friends, knowing and seeing thus, do you, by supernormal power, create a mind-made body?”

original: samannāgatā vacīduccaritena samannāgatā manoduccaritena samannāgatā, ariyānaṁ upavādakā🔽micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ
analyzed: samannāgatāḥ vacī duccaritena samannāgatāḥ manaḥ uduccaritena samannāgatāḥ ariyānam upavādakāḥ  micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhi kamma samādānā te kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā apāyam duggati
translated: “Do you, knowing and seeing thus, see beings passing away and being reborn, inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, fortunate and unfortunate, and understand how beings pass on according to their actions?”

original: vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapannā; ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā vacīsucaritena🔽samannāgatā manosucaritena samannāgatā, ariyānaṁ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā
analyzed: vinipātam nirayam upapannāḥ ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāya su caritena samannāgatāḥ vacī su caritena 🔽samannāgatā manaḥ su caritena samannāgatā ariyānam an upavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhi kamma samādānā
translated: “These worthy beings who are of bad conduct by body, speech, and mind, who revile the noble ones, have wrong view and act accordingly, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a place of loss, a bad destination, a lower realm, hell.🔽But these worthy beings who are of good conduct by body, speech, and mind, who do not revile the noble ones, have right view and act accordingly, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good destination, a heavenly world.”

original: te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannā’ti, iti dibbena cakkhunā🔽visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passatha cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe
analyzed: te kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā sugatim saggam lokam upapannā ti iti dibbena cakkhunā  visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena satte passatha cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe
translated: and after death they have re-arisen in a good place, a heavenly world.’

original: dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāthā”ti?
analyzed: dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānātha ati
translated: In this way you see with the divine eye, which is purified and surpasses the human, beings passing away and re-appearing, and you understand how beings pass on according to their actions.”

analyzed: na u ha itas āvuso
translated: “No, friend.”

original: “Api pana tumhe āyasmanto evaṁ jānantā evaṁ passantā ye te santā vimokkhā atikkamma rūpe āruppā, te kāyena phusitvā viharathā”ti?
analyzed: api pana tumhe āyasmantaḥ evam jānantāḥ evam passantāḥ ye te santā vimokkhā atikkamma rūpe āruppā te kāyena phusitvā viharatha ati
translated: “But, venerable friends, knowing and seeing thus, do you dwell in those peaceful deliverances that transcend forms, the formless attainments, having touched them with the body?”

analyzed: na u ha itas āvuso
translated: “No, friend.”

original: “Ettha dāni āyasmanto idañca veyyākaraṇaṁ imesañca dhammānaṁ asamāpatti; idaṁ no, āvuso, kathan”ti?
analyzed: ettha dāni āyasmantaḥ idam ca veyyākaraṇam imesaṃ ca dhammānaṃ asamāpatti idam no āvuso kathanti
translated: “Now, venerable friends, this your explanation and your failure to attain these states—which do you place first, and which second?”

analyzed: paññā vimuttā kho mayaḥ āvuso susimā ati
translated: “We are liberated by wisdom, friend Susima.”

original: “Na khvāhaṁ imassa āyasmantānaṁ saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṁ ājānāmi.
analyzed: na khvā aham imassa āyasmantānam saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena attham ājānāmi
translated: “I do not understand the meaning of this statement that you have spoken in brief.

original: Sādhu me āyasmanto tathā bhāsantu yathāhaṁ imassa āyasmantānaṁ saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṁ ājāneyyan”ti.
analyzed: sādhu me āyasmantaḥ tathā bhāsantu yathā aham imassa āyasmantānam saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena attham ājāneyyanti
translated: It would be good if the venerable ones would explain to me in such a way that I might understand the meaning of what was stated by the venerable ones in brief.”

original: “Ājāneyyāsi vā tvaṁ, āvuso susima, na vā tvaṁ ājāneyyāsi atha kho paññāvimuttā mayan”ti.
analyzed: ājāneyyāsi vā tvam āvuso susima na vā tvam ājāneyyāsi atha kho paññā vimuttāḥ mayanti
translated: “You may understand it, friend Susima, or you may not understand it. We are still emancipated by wisdom.”

original: Atha kho āyasmā susimo uṭṭhāyāsanā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
analyzed: atha kho āyasmā susimaḥ uṭṭhāya āsanā yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdi
translated: Then the venerable Susima rose from his seat, went to the Blessed One, and after paying homage to him, sat down at one side.

original: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā susimo yāvatako tehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṁ ahosi kathāsallāpo taṁ sabbaṁ bhagavato ārocesi.
analyzed: ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho āyasmā susimaḥ yāvatakaḥ tehi bhikkhūhi saddhim ahosi kathā sallāpo tam sabbam bhagavataḥ ārocesi
translated: He told the Blessed One all that had taken place,

original: “Pubbe kho, susima, dhammaṭṭhitiñāṇaṁ, pacchā nibbāne ñāṇan”ti.
analyzed: pubbe kho susima dhamma ṭṭhiti ñāṇa pacchā nibbāne ñāṇanti
translated: “Susima, first there is knowledge of the stability of the Dhamma, and afterwards there is knowledge of nibbana.”

original: “Na khvāhaṁ, bhante, imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṁ ājānāmi.
analyzed: na khvā aha bhante imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena attham ājānāmi
translated: “Venerable sir, I do not understand in detail the meaning of what was stated in brief by the venerable ones.

original: Sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā tathā bhāsatu yathāhaṁ imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṁ ājāneyyan”ti.
analyzed: sādhu me bhante bhagavā tathā bhāsatu yathā aham imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena attham ājāneyyanti
translated: It would be good if the Blessed One would explain the meaning of these words. The Blessed One said:

original: “Ājāneyyāsi vā tvaṁ, susima, na vā tvaṁ ājāneyyāsi, atha kho dhammaṭṭhitiñāṇaṁ pubbe, pacchā nibbāne ñāṇaṁ.
analyzed: ājāneyyāsi vā tva susima na vā tvam ājāneyyāsi atha kho dhamma ṭṭhiti ñāṇam pubbe pacchā nibbāne ñāṇa
translated: “Whether you understand it or not, Susima, the knowledge of the stability of the Dhamma comes first, and afterwards the knowledge of Nibbāna.

analyzed: tam kim maññasi susima
translated: “What do you think, Susima?

analyzed: rūpam niccam vā aniccam vā ati
translated: Is form permanent or impermanent?”

analyzed: an it ca bhante
translated: “Impermanent, venerable sir.”

original: “Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vā taṁ sukhaṁ vā”ti?
analyzed: yam pana aniccam dukkham vā tam sukham vā ati
translated: “But if it is impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

analyzed: dukkha bhante
translated: “Suffering, venerable sir.”

original: “Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vipariṇāmadhammaṁ, kallaṁ nu taṁ samanupassituṁ:
analyzed: yam pana aniccam dukkham vipariṇāma dhamma kallam nu tam samanupassitu
translated: “But if it is impermanent, suffering, and subject to change, is it fit to be regarded thus:

analyzed: etam mama esaḥ aham asmi esaḥ me attā ati
translated: ‘This is mine, this I am, this is my self’?”

analyzed: naḥ heta bhante
translated: “No, venerable sir.”

analyzed: vedanā niccā vā aniccā vā ati
translated: “Is feeling permanent or impermanent?”

analyzed: aniccā bhante
translated: “Impermanent, venerable sir.”

original: “Tasmātiha, susima, yaṁ kiñci rūpaṁ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṁ ajjhattaṁ vā bahiddhā
analyzed: tasmā ati ha susima yam kiñci rūpam atīta anāgata paccuppannam ajjhattam vā bahiddhā
translated: “Therefore, Susıma, any kind of form whatsoever that is past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near -

original: vā oḷārikaṁ vā sukhumaṁ vā hīnaṁ vā paṇītaṁ vā yaṁ dūre santike vā, sabbaṁ rūpaṁ
analyzed: vā oḷārikam vā sukhumam vā hīnam vā paṇītam vā yam dūre santike vā sabbam
translated: whether gross or subtle, inferior or refined, far or near—

original: netaṁ mama nesohamasmi na meso attāti; evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṁ.
analyzed: na itam mama na isā aham asmi na mā isā attā ati evam etam yathābhūtam sammappaññāya daṭṭhabba
translated: all material form should be seen as it really is with correct wisdom in this way: ‘This is not mine, this I am not, this is not my self.’

original: Yā kāci vedanā atītānāgatapaccuppannā ajjhattaṁ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikā vā sukhumā🔽vā hīnā vā paṇītā vā yā dūre santike vā, sabbā vedanā netaṁ mama nesohamasmi na meso🔽attāti; evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṁ.
analyzed: yā kāci vedanā atīta anāgata paccuppannā ajjhattam vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikā vā sukhumā  vā hīnā vā paṇītā vā yā dūre santike vā sabbā vedanā na itam mama na iso ham asmi na mā iso  attā iti evam etam yathābhūtam sammappaññāya daṭṭhabba
translated: Whatever feelings there are—whether past, future, or present; internal or external; blatant or subtle; common or sublime; far or near:🔽all feelings should be seen as they really are with correct wisdom in this way: ‘This is not mine, this I am not, this is not my self.’

analyzed: yā kāci saññā pe
translated: Whatever perceptions there are—whether past, future, or present; internal or external; blatant or subtle; common or sublime; far or near:

original: ye keci saṅkhārā atītānāgatapaccuppannā ajjhattaṁ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikā vā sukhumā🔽vā hīnā vā paṇītā vā ye dūre santike vā, sabbe saṅkhārā netaṁ mama nesohamasmi na
analyzed: ye keci saṅkhārāḥ atīta anāgata paccuppannāḥ ajjhattam vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikāḥ vā sukhumā  vā hīnāḥ vā paṇītāḥ vā ye dūre santike vā sabbe saṅkhārāḥ na itam mama na isī uham asmi na
translated: Whatever intentional activities there are—whether past, future, or present; internal or external; blatant or subtle; common or sublime; far or near—

original: meso attāti; evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṁ.
analyzed: mā iso attā iti evam etam yathābhūtam sammappaññāya daṭṭhabba
translated: all intentional activities should be seen as they really are with correct wisdom in this way: ‘This is not mine, this I am not, this is not my self.’

original: Yaṁ kiñci viññāṇaṁ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṁ ajjhattaṁ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṁ vā sukhumaṁ
analyzed: yam kiñci viññāṇam atīta anāgata paccuppannam ajjhattam vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikam vā
translated: Whatever consciousness there is, whether past, present, or future, internal or external, gross or subtle,🔽

original: vā hīnaṁ vā paṇītaṁ vā yaṁ dūre santike vā, sabbaṁ viññāṇaṁ netaṁ mama nesohamasmi
analyzed: vā hīnam vā paṇītam vā yam dūre santike vā sabbam viññāṇam na itam mama na isī ham asmi
translated: Whatever consciousness there is, whether past, present, or future, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near — having looked at all consciousness with right wisdom thus: ‘This is not mine, this I am not, this is not my self,’

original: na meso attāti; evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṁ.
analyzed: na mā iso attā ati evam etam yathābhūtam sammappaññāya daṭṭhabba
translated: one should practice for its fading away.

original: Evaṁ passaṁ, susima, sutavā ariyasāvako rūpasmimpi nibbindati, vedanāyapi nibbindati, saññāyapi nibbindati, saṅkhāresupi nibbindati, viññāṇasmimpi nibbindati.
analyzed: evam passa susima sutavā ariya sāvako rūpasmim pi nibbindati vedanāya api nibbindati saññāya api nibbindati saṅkhāresu pi nibbindati viññāṇasmim pi nibbindati
translated: Seeing thus, Susima, the instructed noble disciple experiences revulsion towards the eye, revulsion towards forms, revulsion towards eye-consciousness, revulsion towards eye-contact, and whatever feeling that arises with eye-contact as condition — whether pleasant, painful, or neither-painful-nor-pleasant: he experiences revulsion towards that too.

original: Nibbindaṁ virajjati, virāgā vimuccati, vimuttasmiṁ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṁ hoti.
analyzed: nibbindam virajjati virāgā vimuccati vimuttasmin vimuttam iti ñāṇam hoti
translated: Experiencing revulsion, he becomes dispassionate. Through dispassion his mind is ,

original: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: brahmacariya katam karaṇīya na aparam itthattāya ati pajānāti
translated: he directly knows: ‘Destroyed is birth, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more for this state of being.’

analyzed: jāti paccayā jarā maraṇanti susima passasi iti
translated: “Do you see, Susima, that birth has aging and death as its consequence?”

analyzed: eva bhante
translated: “Yes, venerable sir.”

analyzed: bhava paccayā jātī iti susima passasi iti
translated: “Do you see that existence has birth as its consequence?”

analyzed: eva bhante
translated: “Yes, venerable sir.”

analyzed: upādāna paccayā bhavaḥ ti susima passasi iti
translated: “Do you see that clinging is a condition for existence?”

analyzed: eva bhante
translated: “Yes, venerable sir.”

analyzed: taṇhā paccayā upādānanti susima passasi iti

analyzed: saḷāyatana paccayā phasso ti

analyzed: eva bhante

analyzed: bhava nirodhā jāti nirodho ti susima passasi iti

analyzed: eva bhante  upādāna nirodhā bhava nirodhā uti

analyzed: taṇhā nirodhāḥ upādāna nirodhā iti  vedanā nirodhā taṇhā nirodhā uti
translated: “Do you see that with the cessation of craving comes the cessation of clinging?”🔽“Do you see that with the cessation of feeling comes the cessation of craving?”

analyzed: saḷāyatana nirodhā phassa nirodho ti

analyzed: nāma rūpa nirodhā
translated: “Do you see that with the cessation of name-and-form comes the cessation of the six sense bases?”

analyzed: viññāṇa nirodhā nāma rūpa nirodhā ti  saṅkhāra nirodhā viññāṇa nirodho ti

analyzed: avijjā nirodhā saṅkhāra nirodho ti susima passasi iti
translated: with the cessation of ignorance comes the cessation of volitional formations?”

original: “Evaṁ, bhante”.🔽“Api pana tvaṁ, susima, evaṁ jānanto evaṁ passanto anekavihitaṁ iddhividhaṁ paccanubhosi—ekopi
analyzed: eva bhante  api pana tva susima evam jānantaḥ evam passantaḥ aneka vihitam iddhividham paccanubhosi ekaḥ api
translated: “Yes, venerable sir.”

original: hutvā bahudhā hosi, bahudhāpi hutvā eko hosi; āvibhāvaṁ, tirobhāvaṁ, tirokuṭṭaṁ tiropākāraṁ🔽tiropabbataṁ asajjamāno gacchasi, seyyathāpi ākāse; pathaviyāpi ummujjanimujjaṁ karosi,🔽seyyathāpi udake; udakepi abhijjamāno gacchasi, seyyathāpi pathaviyaṁ; ākāsepi pallaṅkena🔽kamasi, seyyathāpi pakkhī sakuṇo; imepi candimasūriye evaṁmahiddhike evaṁmahānubhāve
analyzed: hutvā bahudhā hosi bahudhā api hutvā ekaḥ hosi āvi bhāva tiras bhāva tirokuṭṭam tiropākāra  tiropabbatam a sajjamānaḥ gacchasi sā iyyathā api ākāse pathaviyā api ummujja nimujjam karosi  seyyathā api udake udake pi abhijjamānaḥ gacchasi seyyathā api pathaviye ākāse pi pallaṅkena  kamasi sa iyyathā api pakkhī sakuṇaḥ ime pi candima sūriye eva mahiddhike eva mahā anubhāve
translated: “But, Sīha, knowing and seeing thus, do you wield the various kinds of spiritual power, such that: having been one, you become many …

original: pāṇinā parimasasi parimajjasi, yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṁ vattesī”ti?
analyzed: pāṇinā parimasasi parimajjasi yāva brahma lokā api kāyena vasam vattesi iti
translated: you exercise bodily mastery even as far as the brahmā world?”

analyzed: naḥ heta bhante
translated: “No, venerable sir.”

original: “Api pana tvaṁ, susima, evaṁ jānanto evaṁ passanto dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya ubho sadde suṇasi dibbe ca mānuse ca ye dūre santike cā”ti?
analyzed: api pana tva susima evam jānantaḥ evam passantaḥ dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkanta mānusikāya ubho sadde suṇasi dibbe ca mānuse ca ye dūre santike ca ati
translated: “But do you, knowing and seeing thus, with your mind thus concentrated, thus purified, bright, unblemished, rid of defilement, malleable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability, recall your manifold past abodes with their modes and details?”

analyzed: naḥ heta bhante
translated: “No, venerable sir.”

original: “Api pana tvaṁ, susima, evaṁ jānanto evaṁ passanto parasattānaṁ parapuggalānaṁ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāsi—🔽sarāgaṁ vā cittaṁ sarāgaṁ cittanti pajānāsi …pe…
analyzed: api pana tva susima evam jānantaḥ evam passantaḥ para sattānam para puggalānam cetasā cetaḥ paricca pajānāsi  sa rāgam vā cittam sa rāgam cittam iti pajānāsi pe
translated: “But do you, knowing and seeing thus, with your mind thus concentrated, thus purified, bright, unblemished, rid of defilement, malleable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability, understand the minds of other beings and persons, having encompassed them with your own mind?🔽Do you understand a mind with lust as a mind with lust; a mind without lust as a mind without lust;🔽a mind with hatred as a mind with hatred; a mind without hatred as a mind without hatred;🔽a mind with delusion as a mind with delusion; a mind without delusion as a mind without delusion;🔽a restricted mind as a restricted mind; an unrestricted mind as an unrestricted mind;🔽a surpassable mind as a surpassable mind; an unsurpassable mind as an unsurpassable mind;🔽a concentrated mind as a concentrated mind; an unconcentrated mind as an unconcentrated mind;

original: vimuttaṁ vā cittaṁ vimuttaṁ cittanti pajānāsī”ti?
analyzed: vimuttam vā cittam vimuttam cittam iti pajānāsi iti
translated: a liberated mind as a liberated mind; an unliberated mind as an unliberated mind?”

original: “No hetaṁ, bhante”.🔽“Api pana tvaṁ, susima, evaṁ jānanto evaṁ passanto anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarasi,
analyzed: naḥ heta bhante  api pana tva susima evam jānantaḥ evam passantaḥ aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarasi
translated: “No, venerable sir.”

original: seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarasī”ti?
analyzed: sā iyyathida ekam pi jātim pe iti sa ākāram sa uddesam aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarasi iti
translated: “But do you, knowing and seeing thus, with your mind thus concentrated, thus purified, bright, unblemished, rid of defilement, malleable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability, recollect your manifold past abodes with their modes and details?”

analyzed: naḥ heta bhante
translated: “No, venerable sir.”

original: “Api pana tvaṁ, susima, evaṁ jānanto evaṁ passanto dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passasi cavamāne …pe… yathākammūpage satte pajānāsī”ti?
analyzed: api pana tva susima evam jānantaḥ evam passantaḥ dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena satte passasi cavamāne pe yathākammūpage satte pajānāsi iti
translated: “But, Sīha, knowing and seeing thus, do you see any being who arises or passes away, or who is afflicted or liberated?”

analyzed: naḥ heta bhante
translated: “No, venerable sir.”

original: “Api pana tvaṁ, susima, evaṁ jānanto evaṁ passanto ye te santā vimokkhā atikkamma rūpe āruppā, te kāyena phusitvā viharasī”ti?
analyzed: api pana tva susima evam jānantaḥ evam passantaḥ ye te santā vimokkhā atikkamma rūpe āruppā te kāyena phusitvā viharasi iti
translated: “But, Sīha, knowing and seeing thus, do you dwell in those liberations that are peaceful and immaterial, transcending forms?”

analyzed: naḥ heta bhante
translated: “No, venerable sir.”

original: “Ettha dāni, susima, idañca veyyākaraṇaṁ imesañca dhammānaṁ asamāpatti, idaṁ no, susima, kathan”ti?
analyzed: ettha dāni susima idam ca veyyākaraṇam imesam ca dhammānam asamāpatti idam no susima kathanti
translated: “Now, Sīha, this explanation of yours and the non-attainment of those states—how do you construe this in your own mind?”🔽Then the venerable Sīha, having folded his robe in four, and having laid it out flat, lay down on his right side, placing one foot on the other, and mindfulness directed to the fore.

original: Atha kho āyasmā susimo bhagavato pādesu sirasā nipatitvā bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha khalu āyasmā susimaḥ bhagavataḥ pādesu sirasā nipatitvā bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: Then the venerable Sīha, having risen from his bed in the last watch of the night, went to the Blessed One, and after paying homage to him, he sat down at one side

original: “accayo maṁ, bhante, accagamā yathābālaṁ yathāmūḷhaṁ yathāakusalaṁ, yvāhaṁ evaṁ svākkhāte dhammavinaye dhammatthenako pabbajito.
analyzed: accayaḥ ma bhante accagamāḥ yathābālam yathāmūḍham yathā akusala yvā aham evam su ākkhāte dhamma vinaye dhamma tthenakaḥ pabbajitaḥ
translated: and said to him: “Venerable sir, I have committed a transgression in that I was so foolish, so confused, so inept that I claimed an attainment I had not attained.

original: Tassa me, bhante, bhagavā accayaṁ accayato paṭiggaṇhātu āyatiṁ saṁvarāyā”ti.
analyzed: tassa me bhante bhagavā accayam accayataḥ paṭiggaṇhātu āyatim savarāya ati
translated: Please accept this confession so I may restrain myself in the future.”

original: “Taggha tvaṁ, susima, accayo accagamā yathābālaṁ yathāmūḷhaṁ yathāakusalaṁ, yo tvaṁ evaṁ svākkhāte dhammavinaye dhammatthenako pabbajito.
analyzed: tat ha tva susima accayaḥ accagamāḥ yathābālam yathāmūḍham yathā akusala yaḥ tvam evam su ākkhāte dhamma vinaye dhamma tthenakaḥ pabbajito
translated: “Indeed, Susīma, you have made a mistake. It was foolish, ignorant, and unskillful of you to go forth as a monastic in such a well-proclaimed spiritual path and then to be dismissive of it.

original: Seyyathāpi, susima, coraṁ āgucāriṁ gahetvā rañño dasseyyuṁ:
analyzed: seyyathā api susima coram āgucārim gahetvā raññaḥ dasseyyu
translated: Suppose they were to catch a bandit, a criminal, and bring him before the king, saying,

original: ‘ayaṁ te, deva, coro āgucārī, imassa yaṁ icchasi taṁ daṇḍaṁ paṇehī’ti.
analyzed: ayam te deva coraḥ āgu cārī imassa yam icchasi tam daṇḍam paṇehi iti
translated: ‘Your Majesty, this man is a bandit, a criminal. Please punish him as you see fit.’

analyzed: tam enam rājā evam vadeyya
translated: The king would say,

original: ‘gacchatha, bho, imaṁ purisaṁ daḷhāya rajjuyā pacchābāhaṁ gāḷhabandhanaṁ bandhitvā🔽khuramuṇḍaṁ karitvā kharassarena paṇavena rathiyāya rathiyaṁ siṅghāṭakena siṅghāṭakaṁ
analyzed: gacchatha bho imam purisam daḷhāya rajjuyā pacchābāham gāḍha bandhanam bandhitvā  khura muṇḍam karitvā kharassarena paṇavena rathiyāya rathiyam siṅghāṭakena siṅghāṭaka
translated: ‘Go, men, bind this man’s arms tightly behind his back with a strong rope.🔽Shave his head and, with a loud gong, parade him through the streets and lanes of the city.

original: parinetvā dakkhiṇena dvārena nikkhāmetvā dakkhiṇato nagarassa sīsaṁ chindathā’ti.
analyzed: parinetvā dakkhiṇena dvārena nikkhāmetvā dakkhiṇatas nagarassa sīsam chindatha ati
translated: Then take him out through the southern gate and to the south of the city, cut off his head, and throw it away.’

original: Tamenaṁ rañño purisā daḷhāya rajjuyā pacchābāhaṁ gāḷhabandhanaṁ bandhitvā khuramuṇḍaṁ
analyzed: tam enam rañño purisāḥ daḷhāya rajjuyā pacchābāham gāḷha bandhanam bandhitvā khura muṇḍa
translated: The king’s men would bind him tightly with an iron chain around his neck.🔽They would shave his head and,

original: karitvā kharassarena paṇavena rathiyāya rathiyaṁ siṅghāṭakena siṅghāṭakaṁ parinetvā
analyzed: karitvā kharassarena paṇavena rathiyāya rathiyam siṅghāṭakena siṅghāṭakam parinetvā
translated: with a loud-ringing gong, parade him from street to street, from square to square,

original: dakkhiṇena dvārena nikkhāmetvā dakkhiṇato nagarassa sīsaṁ chindeyyuṁ.
analyzed: dakkhiṇena dvārena nikkhāmetvā dakkhiṇatas nagarassa sīsam chindeyyu
translated: and then lead him out through the southern gate and to the south of the city cut off his head.

analyzed: tam kim maññasi susima
translated: What do you think, Susīma?

original: api nu so puriso tatonidānaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvediyethā”ti?
analyzed: api nu saḥ purisaḥ tatonidānam dukkham domanassam paṭisavediyetha ati
translated: Would that man experience pain and displeasure because of that?”

analyzed: eva bhante
translated: “Yes, lord.”

original: “Yaṁ kho so, susima, puriso tatonidānaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvediyetha.
analyzed: yam kho saḥ susima puriso tatonidānam dukkham domanassam paṭisavediyetha
translated: “The pain and displeasure that he would experience because of that

original: Yā evaṁ svākkhāte dhammavinaye dhammatthenakassa pabbajjā, ayaṁ tato dukkhavipākatarā ca kaṭukavipākatarā ca, api ca vinipātāya saṁvattati.
analyzed: yā evam su ākkhāte dhamma vinaye dhamma tthenakassa pabbajjā ayam tatas dukkha vipākatarā ca kaṭuka vipākatarā ca api ca vinipātāya savattati
translated: would be less than the pain and displeasure that would be experienced by one who, in this Dhamma and Discipline that is well expounded, goes forth from the home life into homelessness and then, being discontented with that training, gives it up and reverts to the lower life.🔽This has a worse outcome and a more bitter outcome, and it leads to the nether world.

original: Yato ca kho tvaṁ, susima, accayaṁ accayato disvā yathādhammaṁ paṭikarosi taṁ te mayaṁ paṭiggaṇhāma.
analyzed: yatas ca kho tva susima accayam accayataḥ disvā yathādhammam paṭikarosi tam te mayam paṭiggaṇhāma
translated: But since you have acknowledged your offense in line with the Dhamma, we accept it.

original: Vuddhi hesā, susima, ariyassa vinaye yo accayaṁ accayato disvā yathādhammaṁ paṭikaroti, āyatiñca saṁvaraṁ āpajjatī”ti.
analyzed: vuddhi ha isā susima ariyassa vinaye yaḥ accayam accayataḥ disvā yathādhammam paṭikaroti āyatim ca savaram āpajjati iti
translated: This is the growth in this Dhamma and Discipline: one sees one’s offense as an offense and makes amends in accordance with the Dhamma, and one undertakes restraint in the future.”

analyzed: dasama  mahāvaggaḥ sattamaḥ
translated: The tenth.

analyzed: tassa uddāna

translated: Saṁyutta Nikāya 55.10

analyzed: samaṇa brāhmaṇa vagga
translated: The Group on Monks and Divines

analyzed: jarā maraṇa sutta
translated: Aging and Death

analyzed: evam me suta
translated: Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme
translated: On one occasion the Blessed One was dwelling at Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Park.

analyzed: tatra khalu bhagavān pe
translated: There the Blessed One addressed the bhikkhus thus: “Bhikkhus!”🔽“Venerable sir!” those bhikkhus replied.

original: “ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā jarāmaraṇaṁ nappajānanti, jarāmaraṇasamudayaṁ
analyzed: ye hi keci bhikkhave samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā jarā maraṇam na ppajānanti jarā maraṇa samudaya
translated: The Blessed One said this: “Bhikkhus, there are some recluses and brahmins who do not understand aging and death,

original: nappajānanti, jarāmaraṇanirodhaṁ nappajānanti, jarāmaraṇanirodhagāminiṁ paṭipadaṁ nappajānanti,
analyzed: na ppajānanti jarā maraṇa nirodham na ppajānanti jarā maraṇa nirodha gāminim paṭipadam na ppajānanti
translated: their origin, their cessation, and the way leading to their cessation.

original: na me te, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu vā samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu vā
analyzed: na me te bhikkhave samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā samaṇesu vā samaṇa sammatāḥ brāhmaṇesu vā
translated: “Bhikkhus, those ascetics and brahmins who do not understand aging-and-death, its origin, its cessation, and the way leading to its cessation;🔽who do not understand birth … existence … clinging …🔽they are not worthy of the appellation ‘ascetic’ or ‘brahmin’;🔽they are not at all ascetics or brahmins.

original: brāhmaṇasammatā, na ca pana te āyasmanto sāmaññatthaṁ vā brahmaññatthaṁ vā diṭṭheva
analyzed: brāhmaṇa sammatāḥ na ca pana te āyasmanto sāmañña ttham vā brahmañña ttham vā diṭṭhā iva
translated: “But, bhikkhus, those ascetics and brahmins who understand aging-and-death, its origin, its cessation, and the way leading to its cessation;

original: dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti.🔽Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā jarāmaraṇaṁ pajānanti …pe… paṭipadaṁ pajānanti,
analyzed: dhamme sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti  ye ca kho keci bhikkhave samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā jarā maraṇam pajānanti pe paṭipadam pajānanti
translated: who understand birth … existence … clinging …🔽they are worthy of the appellation ‘ascetic’ or ‘brahmin’;

original: te kho me, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu ceva samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu
analyzed: te kho me bhikkhave samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā samaṇesu ca iva samaṇa sammatāḥ brāhmaṇesu
translated: they are true ascetics and brahmins.”🔽(The sutta is given in full in the same way as in the preceding sutta.)🔽The first section for recitation on the ascetics and brahmins is finished.

original: Sāvatthiyaṁ viharati.🔽“Jarāmaraṇaṁ, bhikkhave, ajānatā apassatā yathābhūtaṁ jarāmaraṇe yathābhūtaṁ ñāṇāya satthā pariyesitabbo;🔽jarāmaraṇasamudayaṁ ajānatā apassatā yathābhūtaṁ jarāmaraṇasamudaye yathābhūtaṁ ñāṇāya satthā pariyesitabbo;
analyzed: sāvatthiyam viharati  jarā maraṇa bhikkhave a jānatā a passatā yathābhūtam jarā maraṇe yathābhūtam ñāṇāya satthā pariyesitabbaḥ  jarā maraṇa samudayam a jānatā a passatā yathābhūtam jarā maraṇa samudaye yathābhūtam ñāṇāya satthā pariyesitabbaḥ
translated: At Sāvatthī. 🔽“Monks, without knowing and seeing the aging and death that arises with birth, the teacher should be sought after for the purpose of knowing and seeing the aging and death that arises with birth as it actually is.🔽Without knowing and seeing the origin of aging and death, the teacher should be sought after for the purpose of knowing and seeing the origin of aging and death as it actually is.

original: jarāmaraṇanirodhaṁ ajānatā apassatā yathābhūtaṁ jarāmaraṇanirodhe yathābhūtaṁ ñāṇāya satthā pariyesitabbo;

translated: Without knowing and seeing the cessation of aging and death, the teacher should be sought after for the purpose of knowing and seeing the cessation of aging and death as it actually is.

original: jarāmaraṇanirodhagāminiṁ paṭipadaṁ ajānatā apassatā yathābhūtaṁ jarāmaraṇanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya yathābhūtaṁ ñāṇāya satthā pariyesitabbo”ti.
analyzed: jarā maraṇa nirodha gāminim paṭipadam a jānatā a passatā yathābhūtam jarā maraṇa nirodha gāminiyā paṭipadāya yathābhūtam ñāṇāya satthā pariyesitabbaḥ ti
translated: Without knowing and seeing the practice that leads to the cessation of aging and death, the teacher should be sought after for the purpose of knowing and seeing the practice that leads to the cessation of aging and death as it actually is.”
